ACT 3:25 You are sons of the prophets, and of the covenant which God made with our fathers, saying to Abraham, ‘Yes, in your seed all the families of the earth will be blessed.’
ACT 3:26 God, having raised up His Servant Jesus, sent Him to you first, to bless you by turning each of you away from your iniquities.”
ACT 4:1 Now as they were speaking to the people, the priests, the captain of the temple and the Sadducees came at them,
ACT 4:2 being upset because they were teaching the people and proclaiming in Jesus the resurrection from the dead.
ACT 4:3 And they laid hands on them and put them in custody until the next day, because it was already evening.
ACT 4:4 (However, many of those who heard the message believed; the number of the men came to be about five thousand.)
ACT 4:5 So the next day an assembly of their rulers, both elders and scribes, occurred in Jerusalem,
ACT 4:6 along with Annas the high priest, and Caiaphas, John and Alexander, and as many as were of high-priestly descent.
ACT 4:7 And having placed them in the middle [of the assembly] they started questioning: “By what power, or by what name did you do this?”
ACT 4:8 Then Peter, full of Holy Spirit, said to them: “Rulers of the people and elders of Israel:
ACT 4:9 If we are being examined today about a good deed done to a helpless man, by what means he has been made well,
ACT 4:10 be it known to you all, and to all the people of Israel, that by the name of Jesus Christ the Natsorean, whom you crucified, whom God raised from the dead, by Him this man stands here before you whole.
ACT 4:11 This is ‘the stone which was despised by you, the builders, which has become the chief cornerstone.’
ACT 4:12 Also, the salvation does not exist in anyone else, because there is no other name under heaven, given among men, by which we must be saved.”
ACT 4:13 Now upon observing the boldness of Peter and John and perceiving that they were uneducated and unskilled men, they marveled; and they recognized that they had been with Jesus.
ACT 4:14 Further, seeing the man who had been healed standing with them, they could say nothing against it.
ACT 4:15 So ordering them to go out from the council they began to confer among themselves,
ACT 4:16 saying: “What can we do to these men? Because, indeed, that a notable miracle has been done through them is evident to all who dwell in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.
ACT 4:17 But so that it spreads no further among the people, let us severely threaten them to no longer speak to anyone in this name.”
ACT 4:18 So summoning them they commanded them absolutely not to speak or teach in the name of ‘Jesus’.
ACT 4:19 But in answer Peter and John said to them: “Whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God, judge for yourselves;
ACT 4:20 because we cannot help but speak the things we have seen and heard.”
ACT 4:21 So threatening them some more they released them, not finding any way to punish them, because of the people, since they were all glorifying God over what had happened;
ACT 4:22 because the man on whom this miracle of healing had been performed was over forty years old.
ACT 4:23 So upon being released they went to their own group and reported all that the chief priests and elders had said to them.
ACT 4:24 Well upon hearing it, with one mind they called out to God and said: “O Sovereign! You are God, the Maker of sky and earth and ocean, and all that is in them;
ACT 4:25 You who said through the mouth of Your servant David: ‘Why did nations snort and peoples plot vain things?
ACT 4:26 The kings of the earth took a stand, and the rulers were gathered together, against the Lord and against His Messiah.’
ACT 4:27 Well, in fact, both Herod and Pontius Pilate, together with Gentiles and peoples of Israel, were gathered together against Your holy Servant Jesus, whom You anointed,
ACT 4:28 to do whatever Your hand and Your counsel foreordained to happen.
ACT 4:29 As for the present, Lord, consider their threats, and grant to Your slaves to speak Your word with all boldness,
ACT 4:30 while You stretch out Your hand to heal and that signs and wonders may occur through the name of Your holy Servant Jesus.”
ACT 4:31 Well when they had prayed, the place where they were gathered was shaken, and they were all filled with Holy Spirit and spoke the Word of God with boldness.
ACT 4:32 Now the multitude of those who believed was of one heart and soul; indeed not one was saying that any of his belongings was his own, but they had all things in common.
ACT 4:33 (Also the Apostles were giving witness to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus with great power.) Yes, great grace was on them all,
ACT 4:34 because there were not any needy among them—as many as were owners of lands or houses were selling them and bringing the proceeds of the sold items
ACT 4:35 and placing them at the Apostles' feet, and they were distributed to each according as anyone had need.
ACT 4:36 So Joses, who was named Barnabas by the Apostles (which is, being translated, ‘Son of encouragement’), a Levite of the country of Cyprus,
ACT 4:37 having a field, sold it, brought the money and placed it at the Apostles' feet.
ACT 5:1 Now a certain man named Ananias, with Sapphira his wife, sold a possession
ACT 5:2 and kept back part of the price for himself, his wife also being party to it; bringing a certain part he placed it at the Apostles' feet.
ACT 5:3 So Peter said: “Ananias, on what basis has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and to keep back for yourself part of the price of the land?
ACT 5:4 While it remained unsold was it not yours, and once sold was it not in your power? How is it that you have conceived this thing in your heart? You did not lie to men but to God.”
ACT 5:5 Well upon hearing these words Ananias fell down and expired! (Great fear came on all who heard these things.)
ACT 5:6 So the young men got up and wrapped him, and carrying him out they buried him.
ACT 5:7 Now after an interval of some three hours his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.
ACT 5:8 So Peter addressed her, “Tell me whether you sold the land for so much.” So she said, “Yes, for so much.”
ACT 5:9 Peter said to her: “How is it that you have agreed together to test the Spirit of the Lord? Look, the feet of those who buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out!”
ACT 5:10 So she immediately fell down at his feet and expired! So upon entering the young men found her dead, and carrying her out they buried her beside her husband.
ACT 5:11 So great fear came on the whole assembly and on all who heard these things.
ACT 5:12 Now many signs and wonders were being performed among the people by the hands of the Apostles; and they were all in Solomon's Porch with one purpose.
ACT 5:13 None of the rest dared to join them, but the people were magnifying them.
ACT 5:14 Believers were increasingly added to the Lord, multitudes of both men and women,
ACT 5:15 to the point that they kept carrying the sick into the streets, placing them on cots and pallets, so that as Peter came by at least his shadow might fall on some of them.
ACT 5:16 Further, the multitude from the surrounding cities also kept coming into Jerusalem, bringing sick people and those who were tormented by unclean spirits, and they were all healed.
ACT 5:17 Then the high priest rose up, and all those with him (being the sect of the Sadducees); they were filled with jealousy
ACT 5:18 and laid their hands on the Apostles and put them in the common prison.
ACT 5:19 But, during the night an angel of the Lord opened the doors of the prison, and leading them out he said,
ACT 5:20 “Go, stand in the temple and speak to the people all the words of this Life.”
ACT 5:21 So upon hearing it they entered the temple about daybreak and started to teach. Then the high priest and those with him arrived and convened the Sanhedrin, even all the council of elders of the sons of Israel, and sent to the prison to have them brought.
ACT 5:22 Well, upon arriving the operatives did not find them in the jail, so they returned and reported,
ACT 5:23 saying: “We certainly found the prison securely locked, and the guards standing in front of the doors, but upon opening them we found no one inside!”
ACT 5:24 Now when the high priest, the captain of the temple, and the chief priests heard these words, they were really perplexed as to what the implications might be.
ACT 5:25 But someone came and told them, “Hey, the men whom you put in the jail are standing in the temple and teaching the people!”
ACT 5:26 Then the captain went with the operatives and brought them without violence, because they were afraid that the people might stone them.
ACT 5:27 So bringing them they set them before the Sanhedrin; and the high priest addressed them
ACT 5:28 saying: “Did we not emphatically command you not to teach in this name? Just look, you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching, and you intend to bring this man's blood on us!”
ACT 5:29 So in answer Peter and the Apostles said: “One must obey God rather than men.
ACT 5:30 The God of our fathers raised up Jesus, whom you murdered by hanging on a tree.
ACT 5:31 Him God has exalted to His right hand as Prince and Savior, to give repentance to Israel, and forgiveness of sins.
ACT 5:32 And we are witnesses to these statements about Him, as also is the Holy Spirit whom God has given to those obeying Him.”
ACT 5:33 Well upon hearing it they became infuriated and started plotting to kill them.
ACT 5:34 But someone in the council stood up (a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law respected by all the people) and commanded to put the Apostles out for a bit.
ACT 5:35 He then said to them: “Men, Israelites, take heed to yourselves concerning these men, as to what you are about to do.
ACT 5:36 For some time ago Theudas rose up, claiming to be somebody; with whom about four hundred men joined up; who was killed, and all who obeyed him were scattered and came to nothing.
ACT 5:37 Later Judas the Galilean rose up, in the days of the census, and drew away many people after him. He also perished, and all who obeyed him were dispersed.
ACT 5:38 So now I say to you, keep away from these men and leave them alone; because if this counsel or this work should be of men, it will be abolished;
ACT 5:39 but if it is of God, you will not be able to overthrow it—lest you even be found to be fighting against God!”
ACT 5:40 Well they were persuaded by him, and summoned the Apostles; after beating them they commanded them not to speak in the name of Jesus, and let them go.
ACT 5:41 So they went out rejoicing from the presence of the council, in that they were counted worthy to suffer dishonor for the name of the Christ.
ACT 5:42 And every day, in the temple and from house to house, they did not stop teaching and preaching Jesus as the Christ.
ACT 6:1 Now in those days, as the disciples were multiplying, a complaint arose from the Hellenists against the Hebrews, because their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution.
ACT 6:2 So summoning the multitude of the disciples the twelve said: “It is not advantageous that we should forsake the Word of God to serve at tables.
ACT 6:3 Therefore, brothers, select from among you seven men of good reputation, full of Holy Spirit and wisdom, whom we will appoint over this need.
ACT 6:4 But we will give ourselves continually to prayer and to the ministry of the Word.”
ACT 6:5 The statement pleased the whole multitude; and they chose Stephen, a man full of faith and Holy Spirit, and Philip and Prochorus and Nicanor and Timon and Parmenas and Nicholas, a proselyte from Antioch,
ACT 6:6 whom they set before the Apostles; and after praying they laid hands on them.
ACT 6:7 Well the Word of God kept spreading, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem kept multiplying at a great rate, and a large company of the priests were obeying the faith.
ACT 6:8 While Stephen, full of faith and power, was doing great wonders and signs among the people.
ACT 6:9 Then there arose some from what is called the Synagogue of the Freedmen (Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and Asia), disputing with Stephen.
ACT 6:10 And they were not able to withstand the wisdom and the Spirit with which he spoke.
ACT 6:11 Then they instigated men to say, “We have heard him speaking blasphemous words against Moses and God.”
ACT 6:12 And they stirred up the people, and the elders and the scribes; and coming upon him they seized him, and brought him in to the Sanhedrin;
ACT 6:13 and they put forward false witnesses who said: “This man never stops speaking blasphemous words against the holy place and the law;
ACT 6:14 for we have heard him saying that this Jesus the Natsorean will destroy this place and change the customs that Moses delivered to us.”
ACT 6:15 All who sat in the council, looking intently at him, saw his face like the face of an angel.
ACT 7:1 Then the high priest said, “Can these things be so?”
ACT 7:2 So he said: “Men, brothers and fathers, listen: The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he resided in Haran,
ACT 7:3 and said to him, ‘Leave your country and your relatives, and come into a land that I will show you.’
ACT 7:4 Then he left the land of the Chaldeans and resided in Haran. From there, after his father died, God moved him to this land in which you now live;
ACT 7:5 yet He did not give him an inheritance in it, not even a footstep. He promised to give it to him for a possession, that is, to his seed after him, though he had no child.
ACT 7:6 Further, God spoke like this: that his offspring would be aliens in a foreign land—and that they would be enslaved and oppressed—four hundred years.
ACT 7:7 ‘I will judge the nation to which they will be in bondage,’ said God, ‘and after that they will come out and serve Me in this place.’
ACT 7:8 And He gave him a covenant of circumcision; and so he begot Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day; and Isaac did the same to Jacob, and Jacob to the twelve patriarchs.
ACT 7:9 “The patriarchs, being envious, sold Joseph into Egypt; yet God was with him
ACT 7:10 and delivered him out of all his adversities, and gave him favor and wisdom before Pharaoh, king of Egypt; and he made him governor over Egypt and all his house.
ACT 7:11 And a famine came upon all the land of Egypt and Canaan, even a great affliction, and our fathers could not find food.
ACT 7:12 But upon hearing that there was wheat in Egypt, Jacob first sent our fathers.
ACT 7:13 On the second trip Joseph was made known to his brothers, and Joseph's family was presented to Pharaoh.
ACT 7:14 Joseph sent and summoned his father Jacob and all his relatives, seventy-five souls.
ACT 7:15 So Jacob went down to Egypt; and he died, he and our fathers;
ACT 7:16 and they were transferred to Shechem and placed in the tomb that Abraham bought for a sum of money from the sons of Hamor of Shechem.
ACT 7:17 “Now as the time of the promise was approaching which God had sworn to Abraham, the people increased and were multiplied in Egypt,
ACT 7:18 until a different king arose who had not known Joseph.
ACT 7:19 This man took advantage of our race and oppressed our fathers, making them expose their babies so that they would not stay alive.
ACT 7:20 At that time Moses was born, and was well pleasing to God; he was nurtured in his father's house for three months.
ACT 7:21 When he was exposed, Pharaoh's daughter took him to herself and brought him up as her own son.
ACT 7:22 So Moses was educated in all the wisdom of the Egyptians; he was mighty in words and deeds.
ACT 7:23 Now when he was forty years old, it came into his heart to visit his brothers, the sons of Israel.
ACT 7:24 Well seeing one of them being wronged, he defended and avenged the one being oppressed, striking down the Egyptian.
ACT 7:25 Now he supposed that his brothers understood that God was giving them deliverance by his hand, but they did not understand.
ACT 7:26 The next day he appeared to them as they were fighting and tried to reconcile them, saying, ‘Men, you are brothers; why do you wrong one another?’
ACT 7:27 But the one who was wronging his neighbor pushed Moses away, saying: ‘Who made you a ruler and a judge over us?
ACT 7:28 Do you want to kill me as you did the Egyptian yesterday?’
ACT 7:29 Well Moses fled at that word, and became a stranger in the land of Midian, where he begot two sons.
ACT 7:30 “And when another forty years had passed, Angel of the Lord appeared to him in the wilderness of Mount Sinai, in a flame of fire in a bush.
ACT 7:31 Well upon seeing it Moses was amazed at the sight, but as he approached for a closer look the voice of the Lord came to him:
ACT 7:32 ‘I am the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.’ Moses started trembling and did not dare to look.
ACT 7:33 So the Lord said to him: ‘Take your sandals off your feet, for the place where you stand is holy ground.
ACT 7:34 I have definitely seen the mistreatment of my people in Egypt, and have heard their groaning; and I have come down to deliver them. So now come, I will send you to Egypt.’
ACT 7:35 “This Moses whom they refused, saying, ‘Who made you a ruler and a judge?’—God sent him as leader and deliverer by the hand of the Angel who appeared to him in the bush.
ACT 7:36 This man led them out, performing wonders and signs in the land of Egypt and in the Red Sea, and for forty years in the wilderness.
ACT 7:37 “This is the Moses who said to the sons of Israel, ‘The Lord our God will raise up to you a Prophet from among your brothers, like me.’
ACT 7:38 This is he who was in the assembly in the wilderness, who was with the Angel who spoke with him on Mount Sinai and was with our fathers, who received living oracles to give to us;
ACT 7:39 to whom our fathers did not want to be obedient; rather they rejected him and turned back in their heart to Egypt,
ACT 7:40 saying to Aaron, ‘Make us gods that will go before us; because this Moses, who led us out of the land of Egypt—we do not know what has become of him.’
ACT 7:41 Well they made a calf in those days and brought a sacrifice to the idol, and started rejoicing in the works of their hands.
ACT 7:42 But God turned away and gave them over to serve the army of the heaven, just as it is written in Book of the Prophets: ‘House of Israel, did you offer me slaughtered animals and sacrifices during forty years in the wilderness?
ACT 7:43 Actually you took along the tent of Moloch, and the star of your god, Rephan, the images that you made to worship; so I will relocate you beyond Babylon.’
ACT 7:44 “The tent of the testimony, according to the pattern that Moses had seen, just as the One speaking to him had commanded to make it, was with our fathers in the wilderness;
ACT 7:45 which, having received it in turn, our fathers with Joshua brought into the possession of the nations, whom God drove out before the face of our fathers, until the days of David;
ACT 7:46 who found favor before God and asked to find a dwelling for the God of Jacob,
ACT 7:47 but Solomon built Him a house.
ACT 7:48 However, the Most High does not dwell in handmade sanctuaries, just as the prophet says:
ACT 7:49 ‘Heaven is my throne, while the earth is a footstool for my feet. What kind of house will you build me,’ says the Lord, ‘or what place for my rest?
ACT 7:50 Did not my hand make all these things?’
ACT 7:51 “You stiff-necked and uncircumcised in heart and ears! You always oppose the Holy Spirit; as your fathers did, so you do.
ACT 7:52 Which of the prophets did your fathers not persecute? And they killed those who foretold the coming of the Righteous One, of whom you have now become betrayers and murderers;
ACT 7:53 you who received the Law as ‘ordinances of angels’ and have not kept it!”
ACT 7:54 Well as they heard these things their hearts were being sawed in half, and they started gnashing their teeth at him.
ACT 7:55 But he, being full of Holy Spirit and looking intently into the heaven, he saw the glory of God and Jesus standing on God's right,
ACT 7:56 and said, “Wow! I see the heavens opened and the Son of the Man standing at God's right!”
ACT 7:57 Yelling at the top of their voice they covered their ears and rushed at him all at once,
ACT 7:58 and throwing him out of the city they stoned him! (The witnesses placed their garments at the feet of a young man named Saul.)
ACT 7:59 Yes, they stoned Stephen as he called out and said, “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.”
ACT 7:60 Then kneeling down he called out at the top of his voice, “Lord, do not hold this sin against them!” And upon saying this he fell asleep. (Saul was in full agreement with his murder.)
ACT 8:1 At that time a major persecution arose against the church that was in Jerusalem, so all, except the Apostles, were scattered throughout the regions of Judea and Samaria.
ACT 8:2 (Devout men had buried Stephen and made a great lamentation over him.)
ACT 8:3 As for Saul, he was trying to destroy the Church; invading house after house and dragging away both men and women, he was putting them in prison.
ACT 8:4 So on their part those who were scattered abroad went about preaching the Word.
ACT 8:5 Now Philip, having gone down to a city of Samaria, was proclaiming the Christ to them;
ACT 8:6 and the crowds gave heed with one accord to what Philip was saying, as they heard the words and saw the signs that he kept performing.
ACT 8:7 Because unclean spirits came out screaming from many who had them, and many who were paralyzed and lame were healed.
ACT 8:8 Yes, there was great joy in that city!
ACT 8:9 Now a certain man named Simon was in the city first, practicing sorcery and astounding the people of Samaria, affirming himself to be someone great,
ACT 8:10 to whom they used to pay attention, from the least to the greatest, saying, “This man is the great power of God.”
ACT 8:11 They listened to him because he had amazed them with his sorceries for a long time.
ACT 8:12 But, when they believed Philip, as he proclaimed the good news concerning the Kingdom of God and the name, Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
ACT 8:13 Even Simon himself believed, and having been baptized he stayed right with Philip; observing miracles and signs occurring, he was amazed.
ACT 8:14 Now when the Apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent Peter and John to them,
ACT 8:15 who upon coming down prayed about them, so that they might receive Holy Spirit,
ACT 8:16 because He had not yet fallen upon any of them; they had only been baptized into the name of Jesus, the Christ.
ACT 8:17 Then they laid their hands upon them and they received Holy Spirit.
ACT 8:18 Well, upon observing that the Holy Spirit was given through the laying on of the Apostles' hands, Simon offered them money
ACT 8:19 saying, “Give this power to me also, that anyone on whom I lay hands may receive Holy Spirit.”
ACT 8:20 But Peter said to him: “May your silver go with you into perdition, for thinking that the gift of God could be acquired with money!
ACT 8:21 You have neither part nor portion in this matter, because your heart is not right before God.
ACT 8:22 Turn away therefore from this your wickedness and make petition to God, in case the intent of your heart may be forgiven you;
ACT 8:23 for I see you being into a gall of bitterness and a fetter of unrighteousness.”
ACT 8:24 So in answer Simon said, “You make petition to the Lord on my behalf, so that nothing of what you have spoken may come upon me!”
ACT 8:25 So when they had both thoroughly testified and spoken the Word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem; they also evangelized many Samaritan villages.
ACT 8:26 Then an angel of the Lord spoke to Philip saying, “Get up and go south on the road that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza; it is desolate.”
ACT 8:27 So he got up and went; and there, a man, an Ethiopian, a eunuch, a court-official of Candace the queen of the Ethiopians, who was over all her treasury, who had come worshiping to Jerusalem
ACT 8:28 —he was returning, sitting in his chariot and reading aloud the prophet Isaiah.
ACT 8:29 And the Spirit said to Philip, “Go forward and join this chariot.”
ACT 8:30 So running up Philip heard him reading the prophet Isaiah and said, “Do you really understand what you are reading?”
ACT 8:31 So he said, “Well how can I, unless someone guides me?” And he urged Philip to come up and sit with him.
ACT 8:32 Now the portion of the Scripture that he was reading was this: “He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; and as a lamb before its shearer is silent, so He does not open His mouth.
ACT 8:33 In His humiliation His justice was removed, and who will recount His generation? Because His life is removed from the earth.”
ACT 8:34 So continuing the eunuch said to Philip, “I ask you, about whom does the prophet say this, about himself or about someone else?”
ACT 8:35 So opening his mouth and beginning from this Scripture, Philip preached Jesus to him.
ACT 8:36 Now as they were going down the road they came upon some water, and the eunuch said: “Look, water! What is keeping me from being baptized?”
ACT 8:38 So he ordered the chariot to stop, and they both went down into the water, both Philip and the eunuch, and he baptized him.
ACT 8:39 Now when they came up out of the water, Spirit of the Lord snatched Philip away, and the eunuch did not see him any more, because he went on his way rejoicing.
ACT 8:40 Philip was found at Azotus, and as he passed through he evangelized all the towns until he came to Caesarea.
ACT 9:1 Meanwhile Saul, still exhaling murderous threats against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest
ACT 9:2 and asked for letters from him to the synagogues of Damascus, so that if he should find any who were of the Way, whether men or women, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.
ACT 9:3 So it happened, as he was going, that he got close to Damascus, and suddenly a light from heaven shone around him;
ACT 9:4 and falling to the ground he heard a voice saying to him, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?”
ACT 9:5 So he said, “Who are you, Lord?” So the Lord said, “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting;
ACT 9:6 but get up and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do.”
ACT 9:7 The men who were traveling with him stood speechless, hearing the sound but seeing no one.
ACT 9:8 Then Saul got up from the ground, and upon opening his eyes he saw no one; so leading him by the hand they brought him into Damascus.
ACT 9:9 He was without sight for three days, and neither ate nor drank.
ACT 9:10 Now there was a certain disciple at Damascus named Ananias, and the Lord said to him in a vision, “Ananias!” So he said, “Here I am, Lord.”
ACT 9:11 So the Lord said to him: “Get up and go to the street called Straight, and at the house of Judas inquire by name for Saul of Tarsus; because, you see, he is praying,
ACT 9:12 and in a vision he has seen a man named Ananias coming in and placing a hand on him, so that he might recover his sight.”
ACT 9:13 But Ananias answered: “Lord, I have heard from many about this man, how many evil things he has done to Your saints in Jerusalem.
ACT 9:14 Moreover here he has authority from the chief priests to bind all who are calling on Your name.”
ACT 9:15 But the Lord said to him: “Get moving, because this man is a chosen vessel to me, to carry my name before nations and kings, also the children of Israel;
ACT 9:16 for I will show him how many things he must suffer for my name's sake.”
ACT 9:17 So Ananias went and entered the house, and placing his hands on him he said, “Brother Saul, the Lord, who appeared to you on the road by which you came, has sent me so that you may recover your sight and be filled by Holy Spirit.”
ACT 9:18 Immediately something like scales fell from his eyes, and he recovered his sight forthwith; and getting up he was baptized,
ACT 9:19 and upon receiving food he was strengthened. So Saul was with the disciples in Damascus for a number of days.
ACT 9:20 Immediately he started proclaiming Jesus in the synagogues, that He is the Son of the God.
ACT 9:21 Well, all who heard him were astounded and started saying: “Isn't this the one who tried to destroy, in Jerusalem, those who called on this name? Even here he had come with that purpose, that he might take them bound to the high priests.”
ACT 9:22 But Saul kept growing stronger and kept on confounding the Jews who lived in Damascus, proving that ‘This One is the Christ.’
ACT 9:23 Now when a good many days had passed, the Jews plotted to kill him;
ACT 9:24 but their plot became known to Saul. They started watching the gates day and night, so that they might kill him;
ACT 9:25 so the disciples took him by night and passed him through the wall, lowering him in a hamper.
ACT 9:26 Now upon arriving in Jerusalem Saul kept trying to join himself to the disciples; but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was a disciple.
ACT 9:27 But Barnabas took him in tow and brought him to the apostles, and described to them how he had seen the Lord on the road, and that He had spoken to him, and how in Damascus he had spoken fearlessly in the name of the Lord Jesus.
ACT 9:28 So he was with them in Jerusalem, going in and out, and speaking fearlessly in the name of Jesus.
ACT 9:29 He kept on speaking and debating with the Hellenists, so they started trying to kill him.
ACT 9:30 Upon finding it out, the brothers brought him down to Caesarea and sent him off to Tarsus.
ACT 9:31 So then the congregations throughout all Judea and Galilee, and Samaria, had peace and were built up; and proceeding in the fear of the Lord and in the enabling of the Holy Spirit they were being multiplied.
ACT 9:32 Now it happened, as Peter went through all those parts, that he also went down to the saints who were living in Lydda.
ACT 9:33 And there he found a certain man named Aeneas who was paralyzed—he had been lying on a pallet for eight years.
ACT 9:34 Peter said to him: “Aeneas, Jesus the Messiah is healing you. Get up and make your bed!” And immediately he stood up!
ACT 9:35 All who were living in Lydda and Sharon saw him, and they turned to the Lord.
ACT 9:36 Now there was a certain disciple in Joppa named Tabitha, which is translated Dorcas. This woman was full of good works and charitable deeds that she kept doing.
ACT 9:37 But it happened in those days that she took sick and died; so when they had washed her they placed her in the upper room.
ACT 9:38 Now Lydda was near Joppa; the disciples, having heard that Peter was there, sent to him imploring him not to delay in coming to them.
ACT 9:39 So Peter got up and went with them; upon arriving they took him up to the upper room; all the widows stood around him weeping and showing the coats and garments that Dorcas was making while she was with them.
ACT 9:40 So Peter put them all out, kneeled down and prayed. Turning to the body he said, “Tabitha, get up!” So she opened her eyes, and upon seeing Peter she sat up.
ACT 9:41 Then he gave her a hand and lifted her up, and calling the saints and widows he presented her alive.
ACT 9:42 And it became known throughout all Joppa, and many believed on the Lord.
ACT 9:43 So it was that he stayed many days in Joppa with a certain Simon, a tanner.
ACT 10:1 Now there was a certain man in Caesarea named Cornelius, a centurion of what was called the Italian Regiment,
ACT 10:2 devout and fearing God with all his household, both giving alms generously to the people and praying to God about everything.
ACT 10:3 About the ninth hour of the day, in a vision, he saw clearly an angel of God entering his presence and saying to him, “Cornelius!”
ACT 10:4 Well, staring at him and being frightened he said, “What is it, Lord?” So he said to him: “Your prayers and your alms have come up for a memorial before God.
ACT 10:5 Now send men to Joppa and summon Simon, who is surnamed Peter;
ACT 10:6 he is lodging with one Simon, a tanner, whose house is by the sea.”
ACT 10:7 So when the angel who spoke to him had departed, Cornelius called two of his household servants and a devout soldier from among those who were faithful to him,
ACT 10:8 and explaining everything to them he sent them to Joppa.
ACT 10:9 Now on the next day, as they were traveling and drawing near to the city, Peter went up on the housetop to pray at about noon.
ACT 10:10 Well he became hungry and wanted to eat; but while they were preparing, a trance fell on him,
ACT 10:11 and he saw the heaven opened and a container like a great sheet descending to him—it was tied at the four corners and was being let down to the earth—
ACT 10:12 in which were all kinds of four-footed animals of the earth (both wild animals and reptiles) and birds of the sky.
ACT 10:13 Then a voice came to him, “Get up, Peter, slaughter and eat!”
ACT 10:14 But Peter said: “No way, Lord! Never have I eaten anything ‘common’ or unclean!”
ACT 10:15 So the voice came to him a second time, “What (pl) God has made clean you must not call ‘common’!”
ACT 10:16 Well this happened three times, and then the object was taken back up into the sky.
ACT 10:17 Now as Peter was really perplexed within himself as to what the vision that he had seen might mean, well the men who had been sent by Cornelius, having inquired and found Simon's house, stood before the gate,
ACT 10:18 and calling out they inquired whether Simon, who was surnamed Peter, was staying there as a guest.
ACT 10:19 So as Peter was pondering the vision the Spirit said to him: “Listen, some men are looking for you;
ACT 10:20 so get up and go downstairs; and go with them, doubting nothing, for I have sent them.”
ACT 10:21 So going down to the men Peter said: “Yes, I am the one you are looking for. For what reason have you come?”
ACT 10:22 So they said: “Cornelius, a centurion, a righteous and God-fearing man, well spoken of by all the nation of the Jews, was divinely instructed by an angel to summon you to his house, and to hear words from you.”
ACT 10:23 So he invited them in and put them up. The next day Peter set out with them, also some of the brothers from Joppa went with him;
ACT 10:24 and the following day they entered Caesarea. Now Cornelius was waiting for them, having called together his relatives and close friends.
ACT 10:25 So when Peter actually arrived, Cornelius met him, fell at his feet and worshiped.
ACT 10:26 But Peter lifted him up, saying: “Stand up! I myself am also a man.”
ACT 10:27 And conversing with him he went in and found many gathered there.
ACT 10:28 Then he said to them: “You know how it is unlawful for a Jewish man to associate with or to approach a different race; but God has shown me that I should not call any man ‘common’ or unclean.
ACT 10:29 Therefore also I came without objection as soon as I was sent for. So I ask, for what reason did you send for me?”
ACT 10:30 So Cornelius said: “I have been fasting during four days until this very hour; yes, it was the ninth hour, I was praying in my house when wow, a man stood before me in shining clothing
ACT 10:31 and said: ‘Cornelius, your prayer has been heard and your alms are remembered before God.
ACT 10:32 Send therefore to Joppa and summon Simon, who is surnamed Peter. He is lodging in the house of Simon, a tanner, by the sea; upon arriving he will speak to you.’
ACT 10:33 So I sent to you at once, and you did well to come. Now then, we are all present before God to hear all the things commanded you by God.”
ACT 10:34 So opening his mouth Peter said: “Really, I comprehend that God is not One to show partiality,
ACT 10:35 but in every ethnic nation whoever fears Him and works righteousness is acceptable to Him.
ACT 10:36 The word that He sent to the sons of Israel, preaching good news of peace through Jesus Christ—He is Lord of all—
ACT 10:37 that spoken word you know, that was proclaimed throughout all Judea, beginning from Galilee, after the baptism that John preached:
ACT 10:38 Jesus of Natsareth, how God anointed Him with Holy Spirit and power, who went about doing good and healing all those being oppressed by the devil, because God was with Him
ACT 10:39 —yes, we are witnesses of all that He did, both in the country of the Jews and in Jerusalem—whom they also killed, hanging Him on a tree.
ACT 10:40 Him God raised on the third day, and gave Him to become visible,
ACT 10:41 not to all the people but to witnesses who had been chosen beforehand by God, to us, who ate and drank with Him after He arose out from the dead.
ACT 10:42 And He ordered us to proclaim to the people, that is, to testify that He is the One who has been ordained by God as Judge of living and dead.
ACT 10:43 To Him all the prophets bear witness that through His name everyone who believes into Him will receive forgiveness of sins.”
ACT 10:44 While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell on all who were hearing the message.
ACT 10:45 Well the believers of the circumcision [Jews] who had come with Peter were astonished, because the gift of the Holy Spirit had also been poured out on the Gentiles,
ACT 10:46 in that they heard them speaking languages and magnifying God. Then Peter responded:
ACT 10:47 “Surely no one can forbid the water, can he, that these should not be baptized who received the Holy Spirit just like we did?”
ACT 10:48 So he commanded them to be baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus. Then they asked him to stay a few days.
ACT 11:1 Now the Apostles and the brothers throughout Judea heard that the Gentiles had also received the word of God.
ACT 11:2 When Peter went up to Jerusalem, those of the circumcision party started contending with him,
ACT 11:3 saying, “You went in to uncircumcised men and ate with them!”
ACT 11:4 So Peter began by explaining it to them in order, saying:
ACT 11:5 “I was in the town of Joppa praying, and in a trance I saw a vision: a certain object like a great sheet coming down out of the sky, being lowered by its four corners; and it came to me.
ACT 11:6 Upon peering into it I observed and distinguished the quadrupeds of the earth—both the wild animals and the reptiles—and the birds of the sky.
ACT 11:7 Then I heard a voice saying to me, ‘Get up, Peter, slaughter and eat!’
ACT 11:8 So I said: ‘No way, Lord! Never has anything ‘common’ or unclean entered my mouth!’
ACT 11:9 But the voice answered me, a second time, from heaven, ‘Things that God has made clean you must not call ‘common’.’
ACT 11:10 Well this was done three times, and it was all pulled back up into the sky.
ACT 11:11 At that very moment three men stopped in front of the house where I was, having been sent from Caesarea to me.
ACT 11:12 The Spirit told me to go with them, doubting nothing. These six brothers also went with me, and we entered the man's house.
ACT 11:13 He then related to us how he had seen the angel standing in his house and saying to him, ‘Send to Joppa and summon Simon, who is called Peter,
ACT 11:14 who will speak words to you by which you and all your household will be saved.’
ACT 11:15 Well as I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell on them, just as on us at the beginning.
ACT 11:16 I remembered the word of the Lord, how He said, ‘John indeed baptized with water, but you will be baptized with Holy Spirit.’
ACT 11:17 So if God gave them the same gift as He gave us when we believed upon the Lord Jesus, who was I to be able to withstand God?”
ACT 11:18 Upon hearing these things they acquiesced and started glorifying God, saying, “So then, God has also granted to the Gentiles repentance into life!”
ACT 11:19 Now those who had been scattered by the persecution that came about in connection with Stephen traveled as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus and Antioch, speaking the word to no one except Jews only.
ACT 11:20 But there were some of them, men of Cyprus and Cyrene, who upon entering Antioch started speaking to the Greek-speakers, preaching the good news of the Lord Jesus.
ACT 11:21 And the hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number believed and turned to the Lord.
ACT 11:22 Well the report concerning them reached the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they sent out Barnabas to go as far as Antioch.
ACT 11:23 Upon arriving and seeing the grace of God, he was glad, and he kept encouraging them all to remain true to the Lord with purpose of heart
ACT 11:24 (for he was a good man, full of Holy Spirit and of faith). And a considerable crowd was added to the Lord.
ACT 11:25 Then Barnabas departed for Tarsus to look for Saul,
ACT 11:26 and upon finding him he brought him to Antioch. So it was that for a whole year they met with the congregation and taught a great many people. The disciples were first called Christians in Antioch.
ACT 11:27 Now in these days, prophets came from Jerusalem to Antioch.
ACT 11:28 One of them, named Agabus, stood up and indicated by the Spirit that a great famine was about to come upon the whole world (this indeed happened while Claudius was Caesar).
ACT 11:29 Then the disciples, to the extent that any had plenty, each of them determined to send relief to the brothers who lived in Judea;
ACT 11:30 which they also did, sending it to the elders by Barnabas and Saul.
ACT 12:1 Now about that time, Herod the king laid hands on some from the church to mistreat them.
ACT 12:2 James, the brother of John, he put to death by sword.
ACT 12:3 When he saw that it was pleasing to the Jews, he proceeded to arrest Peter as well (it was during the days of the unleavened loaves)
ACT 12:4 —upon seizing him he put him in prison, turning him over to sixteen soldiers to guard him, intending to bring him out to the people after the Passover.
ACT 12:5 Well Peter was being held in the prison all right, but the congregation was making earnest prayer to God on his behalf.
ACT 12:6 So when Herod was about to bring him out, that night Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains, with guards protecting the prison in front of the doors.
ACT 12:7 Suddenly, an angel of the Lord was there, and a light shone in the cell; striking Peter on the side he roused him saying, “Quick, get up!” and the chains fell away from his wrists.
ACT 12:8 Then the angel said to him, “Fasten your belt and put on your sandals.” So he did. Then he said to him, “Put on your cloak and follow me.”
ACT 12:9 So he went out and started following him, not realizing that what the angel was doing was real; he supposed he was seeing a vision.
ACT 12:10 Passing through the first and second guard posts, they came to the iron gate that leads into the city, that opened for them by itself; upon exiting they advanced one block, and suddenly the angel left him.
ACT 12:11 When Peter had come to himself he said, “Now I know for certain that the Lord sent His angel and delivered me out of Herod's hand and from all the expectation of the Jewish people.”
ACT 12:12 Upon reflection he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John (the one called Mark), where a considerable number had gathered and were praying.
ACT 12:13 When Peter knocked at the door of the gate, a servant girl named Rhoda came to answer.
ACT 12:14 Upon recognizing Peter's voice, she was so glad she did not open the gate, but ran in and announced that Peter was standing before the gate!
ACT 12:15 But they said to her, “You're crazy!” but she kept insisting that it was so. So they said, “It is his angel.”
ACT 12:16 But Peter kept on knocking; so when they opened the door and saw him, they were astounded.
ACT 12:17 Motioning to them with his hand to be silent, he related to them how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. Then he said, “Tell these things to James and the brothers.” And going out he went off to a different place.
ACT 12:18 Now as soon as it was day, there was no small commotion among the soldiers about what had become of Peter!
ACT 12:19 Well after searching for him and not finding him, Herod examined the guards and ordered that they be executed. Going down from Judea to Caesarea, he stayed there.
ACT 12:20 Now Herod was very angry with the people of Tyre and Sidon; so they came with one accord to him, and having won over Blastus, the king's chamberlain, they asked for peace, because their country was supplied with food from the king's.
ACT 12:21 So on an appointed day Herod, arrayed in royal apparel, sat on the throne and started to deliver an address to them.
ACT 12:22 But the crowd started calling out, “The voice of a god and not of a man!”
ACT 12:23 Immediately an angel of the Lord struck him down, because he did not give glory to God, and being eaten by worms, he died.
ACT 12:24 And the Word of God kept growing and multiplying.
ACT 12:25 Now Barnabas and Saul returned to Antioch, having fulfilled their mission, also taking with them John, the one called Mark.
ACT 13:1 Now in the congregation that was in Antioch there were certain prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon (the one called Niger), Lucius the Cyrenian, Manaen (who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch), and Saul.
ACT 13:2 As they were ministering to the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, “Set apart to me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them!”
ACT 13:3 Then, having fasted and prayed and laid their hands on them, they sent them off.
ACT 13:4 So, having been sent out by the Holy Spirit, they went down to Seleucia; and from there they sailed to Cyprus.
ACT 13:5 And upon arriving in Salamis, they started proclaiming the Word of God in the synagogues of the Jews (also they had John as assistant).
ACT 13:6 Now when they had gone through the island to Paphos, they found a certain sorcerer, a false prophet, a Jew named Bar-Jesus,
ACT 13:7 who was with the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. This man summoned Barnabas and Saul, really wanting to hear the Word of God.
ACT 13:8 But the sorcerer Elymas (for so his name is translated) opposed them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the faith.
ACT 13:9 Then Saul, also called Paul, filled with Holy Spirit and looking intently at him,
ACT 13:10 said: “O full of all deceit and all trickery, son of a devil, enemy of all righteousness! Will you not stop perverting the straight ways of the Lord?
ACT 13:11 Well now, the Lord's hand is against you and you will be blind, not seeing the sun until next season!” Immediately mist and darkness engulfed him, and he started going around looking for someone to lead him by the hand.
ACT 13:12 Then the proconsul believed, when he saw what had happened, being astonished at the teaching of the Lord.
ACT 13:13 Then Paul and his party set sail from Paphos and came to Perga in Pamphilia (here John left them and returned to Jerusalem).
ACT 13:14 Going on from Perga they arrived in Antioch of Pisidia; and entering the synagogue on the Sabbath day, they sat down.
ACT 13:15 After the reading of the Law and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent to them, saying, “Men, brothers, if you have a word of encouragement for the people, do speak.”
ACT 13:16 So standing up and motioning with his hand, Paul said: “Men of Israel and you who fear God, listen.
ACT 13:17 The God of this people chose our fathers, and prospered the people during their sojourn in the land of Egypt, and brought them out of it with an uplifted arm.
ACT 13:18 For a period of about forty years He put up with them in the wilderness.
ACT 13:19 And when He had destroyed seven nations in the land of Canaan, He gave them possession of their land.
ACT 13:20 After these things, He gave judges for about four hundred and fifty years, until Samuel the prophet.
ACT 13:21 And then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul, a son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.
ACT 13:22 And removing him He raised up for them David as king, about whom He gave witness and said, ‘I have found David son of Jesse a man after my heart, who will do all my will.’
ACT 13:23 God, from this man's seed, according to promise, has brought Salvation to Israel,
ACT 13:24 John having heralded beforehand, in advance of His coming, a baptism of repentance to Israel.
ACT 13:25 Well, as John was fulfilling his course, he said: ‘Whom do you suppose me to be? No I am not—but indeed He comes after me, the sandals of whose feet I am not worthy to untie.’
ACT 13:26 “Men, brothers, sons of the stock of Abraham, and those among you who fear God: to you the word of this salvation has been sent.
ACT 13:27 The Jerusalem dwellers and their rulers, understanding neither Him nor the voices of the prophets that are read every Sabbath, fulfilled them by condemning Him.
ACT 13:28 Though they found no cause for death, they asked Pilate to have Him executed.
ACT 13:29 When they had fulfilled all things that were written about Him, they took Him down from the cross and placed Him in a tomb.
ACT 13:30 But God raised Him from the dead;
ACT 13:31 and for many days He was seen by those who came up with Him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are His witnesses to the people.
ACT 13:32 “Yes we proclaim to you the good news: the promise that was made to the fathers,
ACT 13:33 God has fulfilled the same to us, their children, when He raised up Jesus; as also it stands written in the second Psalm: ‘You are my Son, today I have begotten you.’
ACT 13:34 And that He raised Him from the dead, no longer to return to corruption, He has spoken thus, ‘I will give you the holy things guaranteed to David.’
ACT 13:35 Further, it is stated elsewhere, ‘You will not allow your Holy One to see decay.’
ACT 13:36 Now David, after he had served his own generation by the will of God, fell asleep, was buried with his fathers, and saw decay;
ACT 13:37 but the One whom God raised up did not see decay.
ACT 13:38 Therefore, let it be known to you, men, brothers, that through this One forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you;
ACT 13:39 and by Him everyone who believes is justified from everything you could not be justified from by the Law of Moses.
ACT 13:40 So take care, lest there come upon you that which has been spoken in the prophets:
ACT 13:41 ‘Look you despisers, marvel and perish! For I am working a work in your days to which you will not give credence, even if someone were to explain it in detail to you.’ ”
ACT 13:42 Now as the Jews were going out of the synagogue, the Gentiles implored repeatedly that these words might be spoken to them the next Sabbath.
ACT 13:43 The synagogue service having been dismissed, many of the Jews and the devout proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas, who started addressing them, urging them to continue in the grace of God.
ACT 13:44 Well the next Sabbath almost the whole city was gathered to hear the Word of God.
ACT 13:45 But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with envy and started speaking against the things said by Paul, contradicting and blaspheming.
ACT 13:46 But Paul and Barnabas speaking boldly said: “It was necessary that God's Word should be spoken to you first. But since you reject it, and judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, now we are being turned to the Gentiles.
ACT 13:47 Because that is just how the Lord has commanded us: ‘I have set you to be a light for ethnic nations, that you should be for salvation up to the last place on earth.’ ”
ACT 13:48 Now upon hearing this, the Gentiles rejoiced and glorified the Word of the Lord; and as many as had been appointed to eternal live believed.
ACT 13:49 Well the Word of the Lord was being spread throughout all the region.
ACT 13:50 But the Jews stirred up the devout and prominent women and the chief men of the city, and raised up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and expelled them from their borders.
ACT 13:51 So they shook off the dust from their feet against them, and went to Iconium.
ACT 13:52 But the disciples were filled with joy and with Holy Spirit.
ACT 14:1 Now it happened in Iconium that they went together into the synagogue of the Jews, and they spoke to such effect that a large number of both Jews and Greeks believed.
ACT 14:2 But the disobedient Jews stirred up the Gentiles and poisoned their minds against the brothers.
ACT 14:3 Even so they stayed there a considerable time, speaking boldly for the Lord, who was bearing witness to the word of His grace, giving signs and wonders to take place by their hands.
ACT 14:4 Well the population of the city became divided; some sided with the Jews, others with the apostles.
ACT 14:5 But when a plot was hatched by both Gentiles and Jews, with their rulers, to mistreat and stone them,
ACT 14:6 they became aware of it and escaped to the cities of Lycaonia—Lystra, Derbe and the surrounding area—
ACT 14:7 where they continued to preach the Gospel.
ACT 14:8 Well in Lystra a certain man with helpless feet was sitting (lame from his mother's womb, who had never walked).
ACT 14:9 This man was listening to Paul speaking; who looking intently at him and seeing that he had faith to be healed,
ACT 14:10 said with a loud voice, “Stand up straight on your feet!” And the man jumped up and began to walk!
ACT 14:11 Now when the crowd saw what Paul had done, they raised their voices, saying in Lycaonian, “The gods have come down to us in the likeness of men!”
ACT 14:12 And Barnabas they called Zeus, and Paul, Hermes, because he was the chief speaker.
ACT 14:13 Then the priest of Zeus, whose temple was in front of their city, brought bulls and garlands to the gates, intending to make a sacrifice, along with the crowd.
ACT 14:14 But when the apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard of it, they tore their clothes and rushed into the crowd, crying out
ACT 14:15 and saying: “Men, why are you doing these things? We also are men with the same nature as you, giving you good news, telling you to turn from these useless things to the living God, who made the heaven and the earth and the sea and all that is in them;
ACT 14:16 who in the former generations allowed all the ethnic nations to walk in their own ways.
ACT 14:17 Nevertheless He did not leave Himself without witness, doing good, giving you rain from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and gladness.”
ACT 14:18 Even saying these things, they barely stopped the crowd from sacrificing to them.
ACT 14:19 Then Jews from Antioch and Iconium came, and having persuaded the crowd and having stoned Paul, they dragged him out of the city, supposing him to have died.
ACT 14:20 But as the disciples stood around him, he got up and entered the city. The next day he departed with Barnabas to Derbe.
ACT 14:21 When they had evangelized that city and discipled a good number, they returned to Lystra and Iconium and Antioch,
ACT 14:22 strengthening the souls of the disciples, exhorting them to continue in the faith, and saying, “We must go through many hardships to enter the kingdom of God.”
ACT 14:23 When they had appointed elders for them in every congregation, having prayed with fasting, they commended them to the Lord into whom they had believed.
ACT 14:24 After going through Pisidia, they came to Pamphilia.
ACT 14:25 When they had declared the Word in Perga, they went down to Attalia.
ACT 14:26 From there they sailed to Antioch, from where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work that they had completed.
ACT 14:27 So upon arriving and gathering the congregation, they reported all that God had done with them, and that He had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.
ACT 14:28 And they stayed there a long time with the disciples.
ACT 15:1 Then some men came down from Judea and started teaching the brothers, “Unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses, you cannot be saved.”
ACT 15:2 Well this provoked serious dissension and argument between Paul and Barnabas and them, so Paul and Barnabas were appointed, along with certain others of them, to go up to Jerusalem to the apostles and elders about this question.
ACT 15:3 So being sent on their way by the congregation, they passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, describing the conversion of the Gentiles; and they caused great joy to all the brothers.
ACT 15:4 Upon arriving in Jerusalem, they were received by the congregation and the apostles and the elders, and they reported all that God had done with them.
ACT 15:5 But some of the sect of the Pharisees who believed rose up, saying, “It is necessary to circumcise them, and to command them to keep the Law of Moses.”
ACT 15:6 So the apostles and the elders came together to consider this matter.
ACT 15:7 When there had been plenty of discussion, Peter got up and said to them: “Men, brothers, you know that a good while ago God made a choice among you, that by my mouth the Gentiles should hear the message of the Gospel and believe.
ACT 15:8 And the heart-knowing God acknowledged them by giving them the Holy Spirit, just as He did to us;
ACT 15:9 and He made no distinction between us and them, purifying their hearts by faith.
ACT 15:10 Now therefore, why do you test God by putting a yoke on the neck of the disciples that neither our fathers nor we have been able to bear?
ACT 15:11 Rather, we believe that we are saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus, in the same manner as they.”
ACT 15:12 Then the whole assembly kept silent and listened to Barnabas and Paul reporting what signs and wonders God had done among the ethnic nations through them.
ACT 15:13 Now when they finished, James reacted saying: “Men, brothers, listen to me.
ACT 15:14 Simeon has described how God first intervened to extract from the Gentiles a people for His name.
ACT 15:15 And with this the words of the prophets agree, just as it is written:
ACT 15:16 ‘After these things I will return, and I will rebuild David's tent, the fallen one; yes, I will rebuild its ruins and restore it;
ACT 15:17 so that the remnant of mankind may seek the Lord, even all the Gentiles—the ones, that is, upon whom my name has been called—says the Lord who does all these things.’
ACT 15:18 All His works are known to God from eternity.
ACT 15:19 Therefore I judge that we should not create difficulty for those who are turning to God from among the ethnic nations,
ACT 15:20 but that we write to them to abstain from things polluted by idols, from fornication, from what is strangled, and from blood.
ACT 15:21 For from ancient generations Moses has in every city those who preach him, being read in the synagogues every Sabbath.”
ACT 15:22 Then it pleased the apostles and the elders, with the whole congregation, to send chosen men from among them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas: Judas (the one called Barsabas) and Silas, leading men among the brothers.
ACT 15:23 They wrote by their hand the following: “The apostles and the elders and the brothers, to the Gentile brothers in Antioch, Syria and Cilicia: Greetings.
ACT 15:24 Since we have heard that some who went out from among us have disturbed you with words, unsettling your souls, saying that you must be circumcised and keep the Law—to whom we gave no such authorization—
ACT 15:25 it seemed good to us, having come to one accord, to choose men to send to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
ACT 15:26 men who have risked their lives for the sake of the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
ACT 15:27 So we have sent Judas and Silas, who will also confirm these things by word of mouth.
ACT 15:28 It seemed good to the Holy Spirit, and to us, to place no greater burden upon you than these necessary things:
ACT 15:29 to abstain from things offered to idols, from ‘blood’, from anything strangled and from fornication; it will be in your own best interest to keep away from these things. Farewell.”
ACT 15:30 So when they were sent off they came to Antioch, and gathering the crowd they delivered the letter.
ACT 15:31 When they had read it, they rejoiced over the encouragement.
ACT 15:32 Both Judas and Silas, also being prophets themselves, encouraged and strengthened the brothers with many words.
ACT 15:33 After some time, they were released with peace from the brothers to the apostles.
ACT 15:35 But Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, teaching and preaching the Word of the Lord, with many others also.
ACT 15:36 Some time later Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us return now and visit our brothers in each city where we proclaimed the word of the Lord, to see how they are doing.”
ACT 15:37 Now Barnabas resolved to take John (the one called Mark) along as well.
ACT 15:38 But Paul insisted on not taking someone who had deserted them in Pamphilia and not gone with them to the work.
ACT 15:39 Well the contention became so sharp that they separated from each other. Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus;
ACT 15:40 while Paul chose Silas and set out, having been commended by the brothers to the grace of God.
ACT 15:41 He went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the congregations.
ACT 16:1 So he came to Derbe and Lystra. Well now, a certain disciple was there named Timothy, son of a certain Jewish woman who believed, but his father was a Greek;
ACT 16:2 he was well spoken of by the brothers in Lystra and Iconium.
ACT 16:3 Paul wanted to have him go on with him, so he took and circumcised him because of the Jews who were in those parts, because they all knew that his father was a Greek.
ACT 16:4 As they were going through the cities they were delivering the dogmas to them, to keep—the ones that had been determined by the apostles and the elders in Jerusalem.
ACT 16:5 So the congregations kept on being strengthened in the faith, and were increasing in number daily.
ACT 16:6 Now when they had gone through Phrygia and the region of Galatia, having been forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia,
ACT 16:7 they approached Mysia and tried to go to Bithynia, but the Spirit did not permit them.
ACT 16:8 So they bypassed Mysia and went down to Troas.
ACT 16:9 A vision appeared to Paul during the night: a man of Macedonia was standing, appealing to him and saying, “Come over to Macedonia and help us.”
ACT 16:10 So when he saw the vision, we immediately prepared to go over to Macedonia, concluding that the Lord had called us to evangelize them.
ACT 16:11 So setting sail from Troas, we ran a straight course to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis;
ACT 16:12 and from there to Philippi, which is the foremost city of that part of Macedonia, a colony. We stayed some days in that city.
ACT 16:13 On the Sabbath day we went outside the city by a river, where prayer was customarily made, and sitting down we started speaking to the assembled women.
ACT 16:14 A certain woman named Lydia, a dealer in purple cloth from the city of Thyatira, who worshiped God, really listened, whose heart the Lord opened to give heed to the things spoken by Paul.
ACT 16:15 When she and her household were baptized, she appealed saying, “If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come into my house and stay.” So she persuaded us.
ACT 16:16 Now it happened, as we were going to prayer, that a certain slave girl having a spirit of divination met us, who brought considerable profit to her owners by divination.
ACT 16:17 Following Paul and Silas this girl kept calling out, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who are proclaiming to us the way of salvation!”
ACT 16:18 She kept this up for many days! So Paul, becoming increasingly annoyed, turned and said to the spirit, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her!” And it came out that very hour.
ACT 16:19 But when her owners saw that their hope of profit was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the market place to the rulers,
ACT 16:20 and bringing them before the magistrates they said, “These men, being Jews, are agitating our city,
ACT 16:21 and are advocating customs that are not lawful for us, being Romans, to receive or do.”
ACT 16:22 The crowd joined in the attack against them, and the magistrates tore the clothes off of them and ordered a beating with rods.
ACT 16:23 When they had laid many stripes on them, they threw them into prison, charging the jailer to keep them securely;
ACT 16:24 who, having received such a charge, threw them into the inner cell and fastened their feet in the stocks.
ACT 16:25 Well about midnight Paul and Silas were singing hymns to God in prayer; and the other prisoners were listening to them.
ACT 16:26 Suddenly there was a great earthquake, enough to shake the foundations of the prison; immediately all the doors were opened and everyone's chains were loosed.
ACT 16:27 But the jailer, awaking from sleep and seeing the prison doors open, drew sword, intending to kill himself, supposing that the prisoners had escaped.
ACT 16:28 But Paul shouted out, “Don't harm yourself, because we are all here!”
ACT 16:29 So calling for a light he ran in and fell down trembling before Paul and Silas.
ACT 16:30 He then brought them out and said, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
ACT 16:31 So they said, “Believe upon the Lord Jesus Christ and you will be saved, you and your household.”
ACT 16:32 Then they spoke the Word of the Lord to him and to all who were in his house.
ACT 16:33 In that same hour of the night he took them aside and washed their wounds, and thereupon he and all his family were baptized.
ACT 16:34 Then he brought them into his house and set a meal before them, and he was really rejoicing, having believed in God with his whole family.
ACT 16:35 Now when it was day the magistrates sent the officers saying, “Let those men go.”
ACT 16:36 So the jailer reported these words to Paul, “The magistrates have sent to release you; so now you can leave and go in peace.”
ACT 16:37 But Paul said to them: “After severely beating us in public, although we were uncondemned Romans, they threw us into prison, and now do they toss us out on the sly? No way! Rather, let them come themselves and escort us out!”
ACT 16:38 So the officers reported these words to the magistrates, and they were afraid when they heard that they were Romans;
ACT 16:39 and they came and appealed to them, and leading them out they asked them to leave the city.
ACT 16:40 So exiting the prison they entered Lydia's place, and upon seeing the brothers they encouraged them and departed.
ACT 17:1 Now when they had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.
ACT 17:2 So Paul, as was his custom, went in to them and for three Sabbaths reasoned with them from the Scriptures,
ACT 17:3 explaining and demonstrating that the Messiah had to suffer and rise again from the dead, and that “this Jesus whom I proclaim to you is the Messiah.”
ACT 17:4 Some of them were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, as did a large number of devout Greeks and not a few of the prominent women.
ACT 17:5 But the disobedient Jews rounded up some wicked men from the marketplace, and forming a mob they created an uproar in the city; and attacking the house of Jason, they wanted to bring them out to the crowd.
ACT 17:6 But not finding them they dragged Jason and some other brothers before the city officials vociferating: “These who have upset the whole world have come here too,
ACT 17:7 to whom Jason has given lodging. These all act contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying there is another king—Jesus.”
ACT 17:8 Well they agitated the crowd and the city officials when they heard these things.
ACT 17:9 Then they took a security bond from Jason and the rest and let them go.
ACT 17:10 Immediately, during the night, the brothers sent both Paul and Silas away to Berea; on arriving they went into the synagogue of the Jews.
ACT 17:11 Now these were more noble-minded than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all goodwill, examining the Scriptures daily to see whether these things might be so.
ACT 17:12 Therefore many of them believed, and also not a few of the Greeks, prominent women as well as men.
ACT 17:13 But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that the Word of God was also being proclaimed by Paul in Berea, they came too, agitating the crowds.
ACT 17:14 So then, without delay, the brothers sent Paul away, as if to go by sea, while both Silas and Timothy remained there.
ACT 17:15 But those who were conducting Paul actually took him all the way to Athens; and receiving a command to Silas and Timothy that they should come to him as quickly as possible, they started back.
ACT 17:16 Now while Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was increasingly aroused within him as he observed that the city was full of idols.
ACT 17:17 So he reasoned both in the synagogue with the Jews and devout persons, and in the marketplace day by day with those who happened to be there.
ACT 17:18 Then certain philosophers, both Epicureans and Stoics, encountered him. Some said, “What might this idea-scavenger want to say?” Others said, “He seems to be a proclaimer of foreign deities”—because he was preaching Jesus and the resurrection.
ACT 17:19 So taking him in tow they led him to the Areopagus and said: “May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?
ACT 17:20 Because you are bringing some strange things to our ears, and we would like to know what they might mean.”
ACT 17:21 (Now all Athenians and resident foreigners spent their time in nothing else but to tell, or else to hear, some novelty.)
ACT 17:22 So standing in the middle of the Areopagus Paul said: “Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things you are very religious;
ACT 17:23 because as I went along and scrutinized the objects of your worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: TO UNKNOWN GOD. Now then, the one you worship as ‘unknown’, this is the One I proclaim to you:
ACT 17:24 The God who made the world and everything in it, since He is Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in temples built by hands,
ACT 17:25 neither is He cared for by men's hands, as though He needed anything, since He Himself has always given life and breath to all.
ACT 17:26 And from one blood He made every ethnic nation of men to dwell on all the surface of the earth, having determined their appointed times and the boundaries of their dwellings,
ACT 17:27 so that they should seek the Lord, if perhaps they might grope for Him and find Him, though He is not far from each one of us;
ACT 17:28 because in Him we live and move and have our being. As also some of your own poets have said, ‘For we are also his offspring.’
ACT 17:29 Therefore, since we are God's offspring, we ought not to think that the divinity is like gold or silver or stone—something shaped by human skill and imagination.
ACT 17:30 Such times of ignorance God did indeed overlook, but now He commands all people everywhere to repent,
ACT 17:31 because He has appointed a day in which He will judge the inhabited world in righteousness by the Man whom He has ordained; He has given assurance of this to all by raising Him from the dead.”
ACT 17:32 Well when they heard about the resurrection of the dead, some started scoffing, while others said, “We will hear you again about this.”
ACT 17:33 And with that Paul went out from among them.
ACT 17:34 However some men believed and joined him, among them Dionysius the Areopagite, also a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
ACT 18:1 Now after these things Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
ACT 18:2 And encountering a certain Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla (because Claudius had ordered all the Jews to depart from Rome), he joined them;
ACT 18:3 and because he practiced the same trade, he stayed on with them and worked (their trade was tentmaker).
ACT 18:4 Every Sabbath in the synagogue he would reason with both Jews and Greeks, trying to persuade them.
ACT 18:5 But when Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was constrained by the Spirit, solemnly insisting to the Jews: Jesus is the Christ.
ACT 18:6 But since they kept contradicting and blaspheming, he shook his clothes and said to them: “Your blood be upon your own heads! I am clean. From now on I will go to the Gentiles.”
ACT 18:7 So he moved from there into the house of a man named Justus, a worshiper of God, whose house was next door to the synagogue.
ACT 18:8 Then Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed on the Lord with all his household; and as they were hearing, many of the Corinthians were believing and being baptized.
ACT 18:9 Now the Lord said to Paul by a vision at night: “Do not be afraid; rather speak and do not keep silent,
ACT 18:10 because I am with you and no one will attack you to harm you, because I have many people in this city.”
ACT 18:11 So he stayed on for a year and six months, teaching the Word of God among them.
ACT 18:12 Now while Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews with one accord rose up against Paul and brought him to the judgment seat,
ACT 18:13 saying, “This fellow persuades the people to worship God contrary to the law.”
ACT 18:14 But when Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews: “If there really was some misdeed or wicked crime, O Jews, there would be reason for me to bear with you;
ACT 18:15 but since it is an issue over a word and names and your own law, see to it yourselves; because I refuse to be a judge of such matters.”
ACT 18:16 And he drove them from the judgment seat.
ACT 18:17 Then all the Greeks took Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him in front of the judgment seat. But none of this was a delay to Gallio.
ACT 18:18 Paul still remained there a good while, then took leave of the brothers and sailed for Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila (he had shaved his head in Cenchrea, because he had a vow).
ACT 18:19 He came to Ephesus and left them there (after having entered the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews).
ACT 18:20 When they asked him to stay a longer time with them, he did not consent;
ACT 18:21 rather he took leave of them saying, “I must by all means keep this coming feast in Jerusalem; but I will return again to you, God willing.” Then he set sail from Ephesus.
ACT 18:22 When he had landed at Caesarea, and gone up and greeted the church [in Jerusalem], he returned to Antioch.
ACT 18:23 After spending some time there, he departed and went through the region of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening all the disciples.
ACT 18:24 Now a certain Jew named Apollos, a native of Alexandria, an eloquent man, mighty in the Scriptures, arrived in Ephesus.
ACT 18:25 This man had been instructed in the way of the Lord, and being fervent in the Spirit he was speaking and teaching accurately the things concerning Jesus, although he knew only the baptism of John.
ACT 18:26 So he began to speak boldly in the synagogue. When Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him aside and explained to him the way of God more accurately.
ACT 18:27 When he decided to go across into Achaia, the brothers encouraged him and wrote to the disciples to receive him; upon arriving he was a great help to those who had believed through the Grace;
ACT 18:28 because he kept refuting the Jews vigorously, publicly, demonstrating Jesus to be the Christ, from the Scriptures.
ACT 19:1 Now it happened that while Apollos was at Corinth, Paul, having passed through the upper country, came to Ephesus. And finding certain disciples
ACT 19:2 he said to them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” So they said to him, “But we have not so much as heard that there is a Holy Spirit!”
ACT 19:3 So he said, “Into what then were you baptized?” So they said, “Into John's baptism.”
ACT 19:4 So Paul said, “John indeed baptized with a baptism of repentance, saying to the people that they should believe into the One who would come after him, that is, into Jesus, the Christ.”
ACT 19:5 So upon hearing this they were baptized into the name of the Lord Jesus.
ACT 19:6 And as Paul laid his hands on them the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they started speaking languages and prophesying.
ACT 19:7 There were about twelve men in all.
ACT 19:8 During three months Paul kept going to the synagogue and speaking boldly, reasoning and persuading concerning the things of the Kingdom of God.
ACT 19:9 But when some became hardened and disobedient, maligning the Way before the crowd, he withdrew from them and separated the disciples, reasoning daily in the school of a certain Tyrannus.
ACT 19:10 Now this continued for two years, so that all who lived in Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the Word of the Lord Jesus.
ACT 19:11 Further, God kept working unusual miracles by the hands of Paul,
ACT 19:12 so that even handkerchiefs or aprons that he touched were applied to the sick, and the diseases left them and the wicked spirits went out from them.
ACT 19:13 Well some among the itinerant Jewish exorcists attempted to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had wicked spirits saying, “We adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul preaches.”
ACT 19:14 In fact there were seven sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, who were doing this.
ACT 19:15 But a particular wicked spirit reacted and said, “Jesus I know, and I am acquainted with Paul, but who are you?”
ACT 19:16 And the man in whom the wicked spirit was jumped on them and overpowered them; he was so much stronger that they ran out of that house naked and wounded.
ACT 19:17 Now this became known to all, both Jews and Greeks, who lived in Ephesus; and fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was being exalted.
ACT 19:18 And many of those who had believed started coming, confessing and disclosing their practices.
ACT 19:19 In fact, many of those who had practiced magic brought their books together and burned them up, in front of everybody (they had calculated their value and it totaled fifty thousand pieces of silver).
ACT 19:20 With power like that it was that the word of the Lord kept growing and prevailing.
ACT 19:21 Now after these things were accomplished, Paul resolved in his spirit to go to Jerusalem, passing through Macedonia and Achaia, saying, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”
ACT 19:22 So he sent two of those who ministered to him, Timothy and Erastus, on to Macedonia, while he himself stayed on in Asia for a time.
ACT 19:23 Now it was during that time that a serious disturbance concerning the Way occurred.
ACT 19:24 A certain man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Artemis, habitually brought in plenty of business for the artisans;
ACT 19:25 he called them together, along with the workmen in related trades, and said: “Men, you know that our prosperity depends on this trade.
ACT 19:26 And you observe and hear that not only in Ephesus but throughout almost all Asia this Paul has persuaded and turned away many people, saying that handmade things are not gods.
ACT 19:27 So not only is this trade of ours in danger of falling into disrepute, but also the temple of the great goddess Artemis may be discredited, and even her own majesty be destroyed, whom all Asia and the world worship.”
ACT 19:28 Now upon hearing this they were filled with anger and began shouting, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
ACT 19:29 So the whole city was filled with confusion, and they rushed into the theater with one accord (they had seized Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians, Paul's traveling companions).
ACT 19:30 When Paul wanted to go in to the people, the disciples would not let him.
ACT 19:31 Even some of the officials of Asia, being his friends, sent word to him and urged him not to venture into the theater.
ACT 19:32 The assembly was in confusion: some were shouting one thing and some another; most of them did not know why they had come together.
ACT 19:33 Then the Jews pushed Alexander forward, out from the crowd. So Alexander motioned with his hand and would have made a defense to the people.
ACT 19:34 But when they realized he was a Jew, they all shouted in unison for about two hours, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
