2CO 4:7 Further, we have this treasure in jars of clay, so that this all-surpassing power may be of God and not from ourselves
2CO 4:8 —we are hard-pressed on every side, yet not crushed; perplexed, but not in despair;
2CO 4:9 persecuted, yet not abandoned; knocked down, but not out;
2CO 4:10 always carrying about in the body the putting to death of the Lord Jesus, so that also the life of Jesus may be manifested in our body.
2CO 4:11 For we, the living, are always being handed over to death for Jesus' sake, so that also the life of Jesus may be manifested in our mortal flesh.
2CO 4:12 So then, death is at work in us, but life in you.
2CO 4:13 Now since we have the same spirit of faith, just like it is written, “I believed; therefore I spoke,” we also believe and therefore speak,
2CO 4:14 knowing that He who raised the Lord Jesus will also raise us through Jesus and present us together with you.
2CO 4:15 So all this is for your benefit, so that the grace that has spread through the many may cause the thanksgiving to abound to the glory of God.
2CO 4:16 Therefore we do not lose heart—even though our outer man is wasting away, yet our inner man is being renewed day by day—
2CO 4:17 because our light, momentary affliction is working out for us an eternal and limitless measure of glory,
2CO 4:18 as we do not focus on the seen, but on the not seen; for what is seen is transitory, but what is unseen is eternal.
2CO 5:1 Now then, we know that though our earthly, tent-like ‘house’ may be destroyed, we have a building from God (not a handmade house), eternal in the heavens.
2CO 5:2 Further, in this one we do groan, longing to be clothed with our heavenly habitation;
2CO 5:3 since, obviously, once clothed we will not be found naked.
2CO 5:4 Yes, being in this ‘tent’ is a burden, so we groan—not enough to want to strip, but to be really clothed; that what is mortal may be swallowed up by the Life.
2CO 5:5 Now it is God who has prepared us for this very purpose, who also has given us the down payment of the Spirit.
2CO 5:6 So we are always confident, even knowing that while we are at home in the body we are away from the Lord's home
2CO 5:7 —we walk by faith, not by sight—
2CO 5:8 indeed, we are confident in preferring to be away from the body and at home with the Lord.
2CO 5:9 Yes, that is why we make it our aim (whether at home or away from it) to be well pleasing to Him.
2CO 5:10 Because we must all be exposed before Christ's Judgment Seat, that each one may receive his due for the things he did while in the body, whether good or bad.
2CO 5:11 Therefore, since we know the Lord's intimidation, we try to convince people. We are well known to God, and I hope in your consciences as well.
2CO 5:12 We are not commending ourselves to you again, but are giving you an opportunity of boasting on our behalf, that you may have an answer for those who boast in appearance and not in heart.
2CO 5:13 If we are ‘out of our senses’, it is for God; if we are of sound mind, it is for you.
2CO 5:14 For Christ's love impels us, having concluded this: if One died for all it follows that all died;
2CO 5:15 and He died for all so that those who now live should no longer live for themselves but for the One who died for all and was raised again.
2CO 5:16 So then, from now on we regard no one from a fleshly perspective—even if we have ‘known’ Christ in this way, we do so no longer—
2CO 5:17 so then, if anyone is in Christ he is a new creation; the old things have passed on; look, all has become new!
2CO 5:18 And that ‘all’ is from the God who has reconciled us to Himself through Jesus Christ and given us the ministry of the reconciliation,
2CO 5:19 namely that in Christ God was reconciling the world to Himself, not imputing their trespasses to them, including committing to us the message of this reconciliation.
2CO 5:20 So then, we are Christ's ambassadors, as though God were making His appeal through us. We implore you on Christ's behalf: Be reconciled to God!
2CO 5:21 Because He made the One who did not know sin to be sin on our behalf, so that in Him we might become God's righteousness.
2CO 6:1 So working together we really urge you not to receive God's grace in vain,
2CO 6:2 for He says: “At a favorable time I listened to you, and in a day of salvation I aided you.” Well, right now is a really favorable time; indeed, the day of salvation is now!
2CO 6:3 (We give no occasion for offense in anything, that the ministry not be faulted;
2CO 6:4 rather we commend ourselves as God's servants in every way with great endurance—in afflictions, in hardships, in distress,
2CO 6:5 in beatings, in imprisonments, in tumults, in hard work, in sleepless nights, in fastings;
2CO 6:6 by purity, by knowledge, by patience, by kindness, by the Holy Spirit, by sincere love,
2CO 6:7 by truthful speech, by God's power, with the weapons of the righteousness in the right hand and in the left;
2CO 6:8 through glory and dishonor, through defamation and good repute; as ‘deceivers’ and true,
2CO 6:9 as unknown and well known, as dying and we live on, as chastened and not killed;
2CO 6:10 as sorrowful yet always rejoicing, as poor yet making many rich, as having nothing and yet possessing everything!)
2CO 6:11 O Corinthians! We have spoken openly to you, our heart is open wide.
2CO 6:12 You are not restricted by us, but you are restricted in your affections.
2CO 6:13 Now in return for the same (I speak as to my children), you also be wide open.
2CO 6:14 Do not enter a mismatch with unbelievers; for what do righteousness and lawlessness have in common? And what fellowship does light have with darkness?
2CO 6:15 And what agreement is there between Christ and Belial? Or what portion can a believer share with an unbeliever?
2CO 6:16 Further, what agreement can a temple of God have with idols? Because you are a temple of the living God, just as God said: “I will dwell in them and walk among them; I will be their God and they will by my people.”
2CO 6:17 Therefore, “Come out from among them and be separate,” says the Lord, “Touch no unclean thing, and I will receive you.”
2CO 6:18 And, “I will be a Father to you, and you will be sons and daughters to me, says the Lord Almighty.”
2CO 7:1 Having therefore these promises, beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all defilement of flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.
2CO 7:2 Make room for us; we have wronged no one, we have corrupted no one, we have exploited no one.
2CO 7:3 I do not say this to condemn you; I have said before that you are in our hearts, whether to die together or to live together.
2CO 7:4 I have great confidence in you; I do a lot of boasting about you. I am filled with encouragement, overflowing with joy in spite of all our affliction.
2CO 7:5 Now indeed, when we came into Macedonia we had no physical rest, but were surrounded by affliction—conflicts on the outside, fears on the inside.
2CO 7:6 But the God who encourages the lowly encouraged us by the coming of Titus;
2CO 7:7 and not only by his coming, but also by how much he was encouraged over you as he reported to us your longing, your mourning, your zeal in my stead, so that I rejoiced even more.
2CO 7:8 Even though that letter caused you sorrow, I do not regret it (though I almost did), because I perceive that the letter made you sorry, though only for a while.
2CO 7:9 Now I rejoice, not that you were made sorry, but that your sorrow led to repentance. For you were made sorry as God intended, so as not to be harmed by us in any way.
2CO 7:10 Now godly sorrow produces repentance into salvation without regret, but the world's sorrow produces death.
2CO 7:11 Just consider your own being caused to sorrow in a godly manner, how much diligence it produced in you—what self-defense, what indignation, what alarm, what longing, what zeal, what punishment! At every point you have demonstrated yourselves to be clear in the matter.
2CO 7:12 So even though I wrote to you, it was not for the sake of the wrongdoer, nor for that of the victim, but, before God, so that your real commitment to us might be made clear to you.
2CO 7:13 We have been encouraged by all this. Because of your encouragement, we rejoiced all the more over the joy of Titus, because his spirit has been refreshed by you all.
2CO 7:14 Because wherein I boasted to him about you, I was not put to shame, but just as everything we spoke to you was true, so also our boasting to Titus proved to be true.
2CO 7:15 Also, his affection for you is all the greater, as he remembers your collective obedience as you received him with fear and trembling.
2CO 7:16 I am so glad that I have complete confidence in you.
2CO 8:1 And now, brothers, we want you to know about the grace of God that has been bestowed upon the congregations of Macedonia,
2CO 8:2 that in a great trial of affliction the abundance of their joy and their extreme poverty produced their extravagant, sincere generosity.
2CO 8:3 Because according to their ability, I bear witness, even beyond that ability, of their own accord,
2CO 8:4 they begged us with much entreaty to receive the gift, the sharing in the ministry to the saints
2CO 8:5 —and more than we had hoped, they first gave themselves to the Lord (and due to God's will, to us).
2CO 8:6 So we urged Titus that as he had made a beginning so he should also bring to completion in you this grace as well;
2CO 8:7 that as you excel in everything—in faith, in word, in knowledge, in all diligence, and in your love for us—that you excel in this grace too.
2CO 8:8 I am not giving a command, but I am testing the sincerity of your love by the diligence of others.
2CO 8:9 For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though He was rich, yet for our sakes He became poor, so that you through His poverty might become rich.
2CO 8:10 So here is my advice in this (since already a year ago you began to give and to plan, this is to your advantage):
2CO 8:11 now you must really finish the doing—not only of the enthusiastic planning but also of the completing—out of what you have
2CO 8:12 (because when the intention is presented, it is acceptable according to what one may have, not what he does not have).
2CO 8:13 Now this is not to distress you so as to relieve others,
2CO 8:14 but by way of balance—at this juncture your surplus alleviates their lack, so that later their surplus may alleviate your lack—yes, that there be balance;
2CO 8:15 as it is written: “He who gathered much did not have too much, and he who gathered little did not have too little.”
2CO 8:16 Now thanks be to God who puts the same earnest care for you in the heart of Titus;
2CO 8:17 because he not only welcomed my appeal but being very diligent he went to you of his own accord.
2CO 8:18 But we have sent together with him the brother whose praise in the Gospel is throughout all the congregations;
2CO 8:19 and not only that—he was actually chosen by the congregations as our traveling companion with this gift, that is being administered by us with a view to the glory of the Lord Himself, and to our own goodwill,
2CO 8:20 avoiding any criticism about how we are handling this abundance;
2CO 8:21 giving thought to blamelessness, not only before the Lord but also before men.
2CO 8:22 Further, we have sent with them our brother whom we have often proved to be diligent in many things, but now much more so, because of our great confidence in you.
2CO 8:23 As for Titus, he is my partner and fellow worker toward you; as for our brothers, they are envoys of the congregations, a glory of Christ.
2CO 8:24 Therefore show the proof of your love (and of our boasting about you) to them as representatives of the congregations.
2CO 9:1 Now concerning the ministry to the saints, it is unnecessary for me to write to you;
2CO 9:2 for I know your readiness, about which I boast of you to the Macedonians, that Achaia has been ready since last year, and your zeal has stirred up the majority.
2CO 9:3 Still, I have sent the brothers so that our boasting about you in this matter not prove to be empty, so that you may be ready, like I said
2CO 9:4 —if any Macedonians were to go with me and find you unprepared, we (not to mention, you!) would be put to shame by this confident boasting.
2CO 9:5 So I considered it necessary to urge the brothers to go to you in advance and finish preparing the ‘blessing’ you had promised, that it be ready, representing generosity and not stinginess.
2CO 9:6 Now then, whoever sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and whoever sows generously will also reap generously.
2CO 9:7 Each one should give as he purposes in his heart, not grudgingly or under compulsion; for God loves a glad giver.
2CO 9:8 Further, God is able to make all ‘grace’ abound toward you, that always having all sufficiency in everything you may abound to every good work—
2CO 9:9 as it is written: “He has distributed around, he has given to the poor; his righteousness endures forever”—
2CO 9:10 yes, the One who supplies seed to the sower and bread for food, so as to supply and multiply your seed for sowing and to increase the yield of your righteousness;
2CO 9:11 you being enriched in everything so as to always be generous, which passing through us produces thanksgiving to God.
2CO 9:12 Because the administration of this service is not only supplying the needs of the saints, but is also overflowing in many thanksgivings to God
2CO 9:13 —on the basis of the proof that this service gives, they are glorifying God for the obedience of your confession into the Gospel of Christ, and for the generosity of your sharing with them and everybody—
2CO 9:14 and in their prayer for you, longing for you because of the surpassing grace of God in you.
2CO 9:15 Thanks be to God for His indescribable gift!
2CO 10:1 Now I, Paul, am myself appealing to you by the meekness and gentleness of Christ (I who am ‘humble when present’ among you, but ‘bold when absent’ toward you).
2CO 10:2 Yes, I beg you, that when I am present I may not have to be bold with the confidence that I will ‘dare’ to visit upon some who think that we are walking in a fleshly manner.
2CO 10:3 Well, we do walk about in flesh, but we do not wage war that way,
2CO 10:4 because the weapons of our warfare are not physical, but are powerful in God for demolishing strongholds:
2CO 10:5 demolishing sophistries and every arrogance that sets itself up against the knowledge of God; taking captive every thought to make it obedient to Christ;
2CO 10:6 being ready to punish every act of disobedience, whenever your obedience is complete.
2CO 10:7 Do you only look at the ‘face’ of things? If anyone has persuaded himself that he is Christ's, let him consider this again with himself, that just as he is Christ's, so also we are Christ's.
2CO 10:8 Now even if I boast a little to excess about our authority (which the Lord gave us for building up, not to tear you down), I will not act ashamed,
2CO 10:9 so as not to appear to agree that it is only with letters that I ‘terrify’ you.
2CO 10:10 Because some say, “His letters are ‘heavy’ and forceful, but his physical presence is weak, and his speech can be disdained.”
2CO 10:11 Let such a person consider this, that what we are in word by letters while absent is just what we will be in action when present.
2CO 10:12 Now we do not dare to class or compare ourselves with some who commend themselves; but they, measuring themselves by themselves and comparing themselves with themselves, are without understanding.
2CO 10:13 We, however, will not boast beyond proper limits, but will stay within the boundaries that God assigned to us, a field that includes you.
2CO 10:14 For we are not overextending ourselves, as though we had not reached you, because we did indeed get to you with the Gospel of Christ;
2CO 10:15 nor do we boast ‘off limits’ in the labors of others, but we have hope that as your faith grows our boundaries will be greatly expanded through you,
2CO 10:16 so as to evangelize the regions beyond you (not to boast in work already done in someone else's field).
2CO 10:17 “He who boasts, let him boast in the Lord.”
2CO 10:18 Because it is not the one who commends himself who is approved, but whom the Lord commends.
2CO 11:1 I could wish that you would put up with a little of my foolishness, but indeed you already are.
2CO 11:2 For I am jealous over you with a godly jealousy, because I betrothed you to one man to present you to Christ as a pure virgin.
2CO 11:3 But I am afraid that somehow, as the serpent deceived Eve with his cunning, so your minds may be corrupted from the integrity that is in Christ.
2CO 11:4 For if someone comes and preaches another ‘Jesus’ whom we did not preach, or you receive a different spirit from the one you received, or a different gospel from the one you accepted, you easily put up with it.
2CO 11:5 Now I consider that I am not at all inferior to the very best apostles.
2CO 11:6 Though I may not be a trained speaker, I do have knowledge—but we have been fully manifested to you in all things.
2CO 11:7 Or did I commit a sin in humbling self so that you might be exalted, in that I proclaimed God's Gospel to you free of charge?
2CO 11:8 I ‘robbed’ other congregations, receiving support from them so as to serve you,
2CO 11:9 and when I was with you and in need, I did not burden anyone; because the brothers who came from Macedonia supplied my need. Yes, I kept myself from being a burden to you in anything, and will keep on.
2CO 11:10 The truth of Christ is in me: this boasting will not be silenced in me in the regions of Achaia.
2CO 11:11 Why? Because I do not love you? God knows!
2CO 11:12 Further, I will keep on doing what I do in order to cut off the opportunity from those who desire an opportunity to be considered equal with us in the things of which they boast.
2CO 11:13 Such men are really false apostles, deceitful workers, transforming themselves into ‘apostles’ of Christ.
2CO 11:14 And no wonder, because Satan himself masquerades as an angel of light.
2CO 11:15 So it is no great thing if his servants also masquerade as ministers of righteousness, whose end will be according to their works.
2CO 11:16 Again I say, let no one think me a fool. But should anyone do so, at least receive me as a fool, that I also may boast a little bit.
2CO 11:17 What I am going to say I do not say according to the Lord, but as though foolishly, in this confident boasting.
2CO 11:18 Since many are boasting according to the flesh, I will too
2CO 11:19 (for you put up with fools gladly, being so wise yourselves!).
2CO 11:20 In fact, you even put up with someone who enslaves you, who ‘devours’ you, who takes advantage, who exalts himself, who beats on your face!
2CO 11:21 Is it disrespectful to say that we were ‘weak’? In whatever anyone is bold (I speak foolishly), I am bold also.
2CO 11:22 Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they descendants of Abraham? So am I.
2CO 11:23 Are they ministers of Christ? (I'm being irrational) I am more: in labors more abundantly, in beatings beyond count, in prison more frequently, in ‘deaths’ often—
2CO 11:24 five times from the Jews I received the ‘forty lashes minus one’;
2CO 11:25 three times I was beaten with rods; once I was stoned; three times I was shipwrecked (I spent twenty-four hours in the open sea)—
2CO 11:26 in frequent journeys, in danger from rivers, in danger from robbers, in danger from my countrymen, in danger from Gentiles, in danger in cities, in danger in wildernesses, in danger in the sea, in danger among false brothers;
2CO 11:27 in toil and hardship, in many sleepless nights, in hunger and thirst, in frequent fastings, in cold and nakedness—
2CO 11:28 quite apart from the other things, my daily disturbances, my concern for all the congregations.
2CO 11:29 Who is weak, and I do not feel it? Who is caused to stumble, and I do not burn with indignation?
2CO 11:30 Well, if I must boast, I will boast of the things that concern my weakness.
2CO 11:31 The God and Father of the Lord Jesus Christ, who is blessed forever, knows that I am not lying.
2CO 11:32 In Damascus the governor under King Aretas was guarding the city of the Damascenes, wanting to arrest me;
2CO 11:33 but I was lowered in a basket through a window in the wall and escaped from his hands.
2CO 12:1 It is doubtless not profitable for me to boast; still, I will go on to visions and revelations from the Lord.
2CO 12:2 I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago was caught up to the third heaven—whether in the body or outside of it, I do not know, God knows.
2CO 12:3 Yes, I know such a man—whether in the body or outside of it, I do not know, God knows—
2CO 12:4 how he was caught up into Paradise and heard inexpressible things, things that a man is not permitted to tell.
2CO 12:5 I can boast about someone like that, but not about myself, unless it be my weakness.
2CO 12:6 Now even if I wanted to go on boasting, I would not be stupid but speak the truth; but I refrain, so that no one will think more of me than what he sees in me and hears from me.
2CO 12:7 Because of the incredible importance of the revelations, to keep me from feeling too important, there was given me a thorn in the flesh, a messenger of Satan to beat on me—to keep me from feeling too important.
2CO 12:8 Concerning this thing I pleaded with the Lord three times that it might depart from me.
2CO 12:9 But He said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Therefore I will boast all the more cheerfully about my weaknesses, so that Christ's power may take up residence upon me.
2CO 12:10 So then, I take pleasure in weaknesses, in insults, in hardships, in persecutions, in distresses, for Christ's sake. For when I am weak, then I am strong.
2CO 12:11 I have been boasting foolishly, but you drove me to it. I ought to have been commended by you, because in nothing have I been inferior to the very best apostles, though I am nothing.
2CO 12:12 Truly the apostolic signs were produced among you with all perseverance, by signs and wonders and miracles.
2CO 12:13 Now in just what were you treated as inferior, compared to the other congregations, except that I myself did not burden you? Forgive me this wrong.
2CO 12:14 Well now, I am ready to come to you a third time, and I will still not burden you, because I want you, not your things—children should not have to save up for parents, but parents for children.
2CO 12:15 So I will gladly spend and be spent for the sake of your souls, even if the more I love you the less I am loved.
2CO 12:16 ‘Ok, ok, I didn't burden you, but being crafty I took you by deception.’
2CO 12:17 Come now, did I actually take advantage of you by any of those whom I sent to you?
2CO 12:18 I urged Titus and sent the brother along—did Titus take any advantage of you? Did we not walk in the same spirit, in the same footprints?
2CO 12:19 Do you still think that we are defending ourselves to you? It is before God we speak, in Christ; but all of it, dear ones, is with a view to your edification.
2CO 12:20 Yes, I am afraid that when I come I may not find you such as I wish, and you not find me such as you wish—may there be no strife, jealousies, outbursts of anger, factions, slanders, gossipings, conceits, disorders—
2CO 12:21 that when I come again my God may not humble me before you, and I will mourn for many who have previously sinned and not repented of the impurity and fornication and licentiousness which they practiced.
2CO 13:1 This is the third time I am coming to you. “At the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established.”
2CO 13:2 As I already said while with you the second time, I now repeat in writing while absent, to those who sinned before and to all the rest: If I come again I will not spare,
2CO 13:3 since you want proof that Christ is speaking through me—He who is not weak toward you but powerful among you
2CO 13:4 (although He was crucified in weakness, He lives by the power of God). Now we also are weak in Him, but we will live with Him by the power of God toward you.
2CO 13:5 Examine yourselves as to whether you are in the faith; test yourselves. Do you yourselves really not know that Jesus Christ is in you?—unless indeed you are disqualified.
2CO 13:6 Well I trust that you will know that we are not disqualified.
2CO 13:7 Now I pray to God that you do no evil; not that we may appear approved, but that you may do what is right (even though we may appear to have failed).
2CO 13:8 For we cannot do anything against the Truth, but only for the Truth.
2CO 13:9 Now we are glad when we are weak and you are strong. And we also pray for this, your perfecting.
2CO 13:10 This is why I write these things while absent, so that when present I may not have to deal harshly, according to the authority that the Lord gave me, for building up and not for tearing down.
2CO 13:11 Finally, brothers, rejoice; restore each other; encourage one another; be of one mind; live in peace; and the God of the love and the peace will be with you.
2CO 13:12 Greet one another with a holy kiss.
2CO 13:13 All the saints greet you.
2CO 13:14 The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all. Amen.
GAL 1:1 Paul, an apostle—not from men nor through a man, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised Him from the dead—
GAL 1:2 and all the brothers with me, to the congregations in Galatia:
GAL 1:3 Grace to you and peace from God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ,
GAL 1:4 who gave Himself for our sins, so that He might deliver us out of this present malignant age, according to the will of our God and Father,
GAL 1:5 to whom be the glory forever and ever. Amen.
GAL 1:6 I am sadly surprised that you are turning away so quickly from the one who called you by the grace of Christ, to a different gospel
GAL 1:7 —it is not a mere variation, but certain people are unsettling you and wanting to distort the Gospel of the Christ.
GAL 1:8 Now even if we, or an angel out of heaven, should preach any other gospel to you than what we have preached to you, let him be accursed!
GAL 1:9 As we have just said, I here emphatically repeat: If anyone preaches any other gospel to you than what you have received, let him be accursed!!
GAL 1:10 Am I just now appealing to men, or to God? Or am I trying to please men? You see, if I were still pleasing men I would not be a slave of Christ.
GAL 1:11 Now I want you to know, brothers, that the Gospel preached by me is not according to man;
GAL 1:12 because I did not receive it from any man, nor was I taught it; rather it came through a revelation from Christ.
GAL 1:13 You have heard of my former conduct while in Judaism, how I was rabid in my persecution of God's Church and tried to annihilate it;
GAL 1:14 indeed I was advancing in Judaism beyond many Jews of my own age, being far more zealous for the traditions of my forefathers.
GAL 1:15 But when God—who set me apart from my mother's womb and called me through His grace—resolved
GAL 1:16 to reveal His Son in me so that I might proclaim Him among the nations/Gentiles, I did not start by consulting with flesh and blood,
GAL 1:17 nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before I was; rather I went off into Arabia, and then returned to Damascus.
GAL 1:18 Subsequently, after three years, I went up to Jerusalem to compare notes with Peter, and stayed with him fifteen days.
GAL 1:19 (I saw none of the other apostles except James, the Lord's brother.
GAL 1:20 Really, before God, I am not lying in what I write to you.)
GAL 1:21 Then I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.
GAL 1:22 So I remained unknown by face to the congregations of Judea (those in Christ)
GAL 1:23 —they just kept hearing that “He who once persecuted us now proclaims the faith he formerly tried to destroy.”
GAL 1:24 And they glorified God about me.
GAL 2:1 Fourteen years later I went up to Jerusalem again, with Barnabas, taking Titus along as well.
GAL 2:2 I went on the basis of a revelation and set before them [the main apostles] the Gospel that I proclaim among the nations/Gentiles.—Now I did this privately to those with influence, lest somehow I might run, or had run, in vain.
GAL 2:3 However, not even Titus, who was with me, was compelled to be circumcised, for being a Greek.
GAL 2:4 This came up because of the false brothers who were smuggled in (who stole in to spy out our freedom, that we have in Christ Jesus, so as to reduce us to slavery),
GAL 2:5 to whom we did not yield, even for a moment, so that the truth of the Gospel might continue with you.—
GAL 2:6 Now from those who seemed to be important (whatever they were makes no difference to me; God shows favoritism to no man)—those with influence contributed nothing to me,
GAL 2:7 but on the contrary, upon seeing that I had been entrusted with the Gospel for the uncircumcised, just as was Peter for the circumcised
GAL 2:8 (for He who was at work with Peter for the apostleship to the circumcised was also at work with me for that to the uncircumcised),
GAL 2:9 and upon perceiving the grace that had been given to me, James and Cephas and John, those reputed to be pillars, gave me and Barnabas the right hand of fellowship, that we should go to the Gentiles, while they to the Jews.
GAL 2:10 They did ask us to keep remembering the poor, the very thing I also was eager to do.
GAL 2:11 But, when Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he was blameworthy.
GAL 2:12 Before certain men came from James, he used to eat with the Gentiles; but when they came he began to draw back and separate himself, fearing those of the circumcision party.
GAL 2:13 And the rest of the Jews played the hypocrite with him as well, so that even Barnabas was carried away with their hypocrisy.
GAL 2:14 So when I saw that they were not walking straight according to the truth of the Gospel, I said to Peter in front of them all: “If you, being a Jew, live like a Gentile and not like a Jew, why do you compel the Gentiles to live like Jews?
GAL 2:15 We natural Jews (and not ‘Gentile sinners’),
GAL 2:16 knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law but by faith in Jesus Christ, we ourselves have believed into Christ Jesus, so as to be justified by faith in Christ and not by works of the law; because no one will be justified by works of law.
GAL 2:17 But if while seeking to be justified in Christ we ourselves were discovered to be sinners, then is Christ a minister of sin? Of course not!
GAL 2:18 “Now if I rebuild the things that I destroyed, I acknowledge that I am a transgressor.
GAL 2:19 For through the law I died to the law in order to live to God.
GAL 2:20 I have been crucified with Christ, so it is no longer I who live but Christ lives in me; what I now live in this body I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself in my place.
GAL 2:21 I do not nullify the grace of God; for if righteousness is through the law, then Christ died for nothing!”
GAL 3:1 O foolish Galatians! Who has bewitched you that you not be persuaded by the Truth—Jesus Christ was clearly portrayed among you as having been crucified, before your very eyes!
GAL 3:2 Just tell me one thing: Did you receive the Spirit by works of law, or by hearing of faith?
GAL 3:3 Can you be so foolish? Having begun in spirit, do you finish in flesh?
GAL 3:4 Have you suffered so much for nothing—if it really was for nothing?
GAL 3:5 Furthermore, He who supplies the Spirit to you and works miracles among you, is He activated by works of law, or by hearing of faith?—
GAL 3:6 just as Abraham ‘believed God and it was credited to him as righteousness.’
GAL 3:7 Now you must know that only those who are of faith are ‘sons’ of Abraham.
GAL 3:8 Further, the Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the nations by faith, proclaimed the Gospel in advance to Abraham: “All the nations will be blessed through you.”
GAL 3:9 So then, those who are of faith are blessed along with Abraham, the faithful.
GAL 3:10 Now as many as are ‘by works of law’ are under a curse; because it stands written, “Cursed is everyone who does not continue in all the things written in the Book of the Law, to do them.”
GAL 3:11 Further, it is evident that no one is justified by law before God, because “the righteous one will live by faith.”
GAL 3:12 While the law is not of faith but, “the man who does them will live by them.”
GAL 3:13 Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse in our place—because it stands written, “Cursed is everyone who is hung on a tree”—
GAL 3:14 so that the blessing of Abraham might come to the nations/Gentiles through Christ Jesus; that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through the faith.
GAL 3:15 Brothers: as a man I speak a covenant; though only of a man, once it has been ratified no one annuls or adds to it.
GAL 3:16 But to Abraham were spoken the promises, and to his Seed. He does not say “and to seeds,” as about many, but “and to your seed,” as about one, who is Christ.
GAL 3:17 Further, I say this: a covenant confirmed beforehand by God in Christ cannot be annulled by the law that came four hundred and thirty years later, so as to make the promise of no effect.
GAL 3:18 For if the inheritance were of law, it would no longer be of promise, but God granted it to Abraham by promise.
GAL 3:19 Why then the law? It was added on account of the transgressions, until the Seed should come to whom the inheritance had been promised; and it was ordered through angels by the hand of a mediator.
GAL 3:20 (Now that mediator is not for just one, but God is one.)
GAL 3:21 Is the law then against the promises of God? Of course not! Rather, if a law had been given that was capable of imparting life, truly righteousness would have been by the law.
GAL 3:22 But the Scripture imprisoned everything under sin, so that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.
GAL 3:23 Now before this faith came, we were kept in custody under the law, in confinement until the coming faith was revealed.
GAL 3:24 So then, the law became our guardian until Christ, so that we might be justified by faith.
GAL 3:25 Now that the faith has come, we are no longer under a guardian.
GAL 3:26 So all of you are sons of God through the faith in Christ Jesus.
GAL 3:27 As many of you as were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ
GAL 3:28 —there is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither slave nor free, there is no ‘male and female’; all of you are one in Christ Jesus—
GAL 3:29 so if you are Christ's, then you are Abraham's seed and heirs according to the promise.
GAL 4:1 To proceed, as long as the heir is a child, he is no different from a slave, though he is owner of all,
GAL 4:2 but is under guardians and stewards until the time appointed by the father.
GAL 4:3 Similarly, when we were children we were in slavery under the basic principles of the world.
GAL 4:4 But at just the right time God sent out His Son, born of a woman, born under law,
GAL 4:5 so that He might redeem those under law, that we might receive the adoption as sons.
GAL 4:6 And because you are sons, God sent out the Spirit of His Son into your hearts, calling, “Abba, Father”.
GAL 4:7 Therefore you are no longer a slave but a son, and if a son, also an heir of God through Christ.
GAL 4:8 But at one time indeed, when you did not know God, you were slaves to those that by nature are not gods.
GAL 4:9 But now that you know God—better, are known by God—how can you turn back to those weak, yes decidedly inferior, basic principles, to which you wish to be enslaved all over again?
GAL 4:10 You are observing days and months and seasons and years.
GAL 4:11 I fear for you, lest somehow I have labored over you in vain.
GAL 4:12 Brothers, I plead with you, become as I am, for I became like you. You did me no wrong.
GAL 4:13 Rather, you know that I preached the Gospel to you the first time in spite of a physical infirmity.
GAL 4:14 Also, you did not despise or recoil at my physical trial, but you received me as an angel of God, even as Christ Jesus.
GAL 4:15 So what about your blessedness? Because I can testify that if it were possible you would have plucked out your own eyes and given them to me.
GAL 4:16 Have I now become your enemy by telling you the truth?
GAL 4:17 They zealously court you—not for good but intending to isolate you, so that you may seek them.
GAL 4:18 Now it is good to be zealous in a good thing at any time, and not only when I am present with you.
GAL 4:19 My little children, for whom I am again in travail until Christ is formed in you
GAL 4:20 —I wish I could be present with you now and change my tone; because I am perplexed about you!
GAL 4:21 Tell me, you who desire to be under law, do you not heed that law?
GAL 4:22 For it is written that Abraham had two sons: one by the slave woman and one by the free woman.
GAL 4:23 However, the one by the slave woman was born according to the flesh, while the one by the free woman was through the promise.
GAL 4:24 I will now allegorize them—these are two covenants: one is from Mount Sinai, bearing children into slavery, which is ‘Hagar’
GAL 4:25 (for this ‘Hagar’ is Mount Sinai in Arabia and corresponds to the present day Jerusalem, and is in slavery with her children);
GAL 4:26 while the ‘Jerusalem’ that is above is free, which is the mother of us all.
GAL 4:27 For it is written: “Rejoice, barren one, who does not give birth; break forth and shout, you who have no labor pains; because the abandoned woman has many more children than she who has the husband.”
GAL 4:28 Now we, brothers, like Isaac, are children of promise.
GAL 4:29 But, it is the same now as it was then: the one born according to flesh persecutes the one born according to Spirit.
GAL 4:30 However, what does the Scripture say? “Expel the slave woman and her son, because the son of the slave woman absolutely must not inherit with the son of the free woman!”
GAL 4:31 So then, brothers, we are not children of a slave woman, but of the free woman.
GAL 5:1 Stand firm therefore in the freedom with which Christ has made us free, and do not be burdened again with a yoke of slavery.
GAL 5:2 Listen! I, Paul, say to you that if you get circumcised, Christ will profit you nothing.
GAL 5:3 Further, I testify again to every man who gets circumcised that he is obligated to keep the whole law.
GAL 5:4 You who are ‘being justified’ by law have been alienated from the Christ; you have fallen away from the grace.
GAL 5:5 For we through the Spirit eagerly wait for the hope of righteousness by faith.
GAL 5:6 Because in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision avails anything, but faith working through love.
GAL 5:7 You were running well; who hindered you from obeying the truth?
GAL 5:8 This persuasion is not from Him who calls you.
GAL 5:9 A little yeast leavens the whole batch of dough.
GAL 5:10 I have confidence toward you in the Lord that you will not think differently; but he who troubles you will bear the penalty, whoever he may be.
GAL 5:11 But I, brothers, if I still preach circumcision, why am I still being persecuted? In that event the offense of the cross would have been removed.
GAL 5:12 I do wish that those who are upsetting you would just remove themselves!
GAL 5:13 Now you, brothers, have been called to freedom; only do not use that freedom as an opening for the flesh, but slave for one another through love.
GAL 5:14 For the whole law is fulfilled in one word, namely: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”
GAL 5:15 But if you bite and tear at each other, beware lest you be consumed by one another!
GAL 5:16 I say then: walk in the Spirit, and you will not fulfill the lust of the flesh.
GAL 5:17 Because the flesh desires what is contrary to the Spirit, and the Spirit what is contrary to the flesh; they oppose each other; it follows that you may not do the things that you wish.
GAL 5:18 However, if you are led by the Spirit you are not under law.
GAL 5:19 Now the works of the flesh are obvious, namely: adultery, fornication, uncleanness, licentiousness,
GAL 5:20 idolatry, sorcery, hatred, strife, jealousies, fits of anger, selfish ambition, dissentions, factions,
GAL 5:21 envyings, murders, drinking bouts, orgies, and the like; about which I am warning you beforehand, as, in fact, I did before, that those who practice such things will not inherit the Kingdom of God.
GAL 5:22 But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness,
GAL 5:23 gentleness, self-control—against such things there is no law.
GAL 5:24 Further, those who are Christ's have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.
GAL 5:25 Since we live by the Spirit, let us also conform to the Spirit.
GAL 5:26 Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.
GAL 6:1 Brothers, if a man is actually caught in some wrongdoing, you, the spiritual ones, should restore him in a spirit of gentleness, watching out for yourself lest you also be tempted.
GAL 6:2 Bear one another's heavy burdens, and so fulfill the law of the Christ.
GAL 6:3 For if anyone thinks himself to be something, when he is nothing, he deceives himself.
GAL 6:4 Let each one test his own work, and then do his ‘boasting’ only within himself, never to someone else.
GAL 6:5 For each one must carry his own normal load.
GAL 6:6 Let him who is taught the Word share all good things with him who teaches.
GAL 6:7 Do not be deceived, God does not allow Himself to be treated with contempt; because whatever a man sows, that he will also reap
GAL 6:8 —he who sows to his own flesh will reap deterioration from that flesh; he who sows to the Spirit will reap eternal life from that Spirit.
GAL 6:9 Let us not lose heart while doing good, for we will reap in due season, if we do not give up.
GAL 6:10 So then, as we have opportunity, let us do what is good toward everyone, but especially toward those who are of the household of the faith.
GAL 6:11 See with what large letters I have written to you with my own hand.
GAL 6:12 Those who want to make a good showing in the flesh are pressuring you to be circumcised, but only so as not to be persecuted for the cross of Christ.
GAL 6:13 For not even those who are circumcised keep the law themselves, yet they want you to be circumcised that they may boast in your flesh.
GAL 6:14 But as for me, may I never boast except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.
GAL 6:15 Because in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision avails anything, but a new creation.
GAL 6:16 Now as for those who conform to this rule, peace and mercy be upon them, and upon the Israel of God.
GAL 6:17 Finally, let no one cause me trouble, for I bear on my body the brand marks of the Lord Jesus.
GAL 6:18 The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, brothers. Amen.
EPH 1:1 Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, to the saints who are at Ephesus, that is, the faithful in Christ Jesus:
EPH 1:2 Grace to you and peace from God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
EPH 1:3 Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly realms in Christ;
EPH 1:4 just as He[F] chose us in Him[S] before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before Him[F], in love,
EPH 1:5 having predestined us into an adoption as sons through Jesus Christ, into Him[S], according to the good pleasure of His[F] will,
EPH 1:6 to the praise of the glory of His grace, with which He graced us in the Beloved;
EPH 1:7 in whom we have the redemption through His[S] blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of His[F] grace,
EPH 1:8 that He made to abound toward us in all wisdom and intelligent design,
EPH 1:9 having made known to us the ‘secret’ of His will, according to His good pleasure which He purposed in Him[S],
EPH 1:10 with a view to administering the fullness of the times, so as to bring all things together under one head in Christ—those on the heavens and those on the earth—in Him[S],
EPH 1:11 in whom we were also assigned an inheritance, having been predestined according to the purpose of Him[F] who works all things according to the decision of His will,
EPH 1:12 so that we should be to the praise of His glory, we who first trusted in the Christ;
EPH 1:13 about whom, to be sure, we had heard the true Word—the Gospel of your salvation; by whom, since you also believed, you were sealed with the Holy Spirit of promise,
EPH 1:14 who is the down payment on our inheritance until the release of the possession, to the praise of His glory.
EPH 1:15 Because of this, having heard about your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love toward all the saints,
EPH 1:16 I really do not stop giving thanks for you, making mention of you in my prayers:
EPH 1:17 that the God of our Lord, Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give you the spirit of wisdom and revelation in the real knowledge of Himself,
EPH 1:18 the eyes of your heart having been enlightened, that you may know 1) what is the hope of His[F] calling, and 2) what the riches of the glory of His inheritance in the saints,
EPH 1:19 and 3) what the exceeding greatness of His power into us who are believing, according to the demonstration of the extent of His might
EPH 1:20 which He exercised in the Christ when He raised Him[S] from among the dead and seated Him at His[F] right, in the heavenly realms,
EPH 1:21 far above every ruler and authority and power and dominion—even every name that can be named, not only in this age but also in the next.
EPH 1:22 In short, He[F] placed everything under His[S] feet, and appointed Him to be Head over everything in the Church,
EPH 1:23 which is His body, the complement of Him who fills everything in every way.
EPH 2:1 He[F] raised you up as well, when you were dead in your transgressions and sins,
EPH 2:2 in which you once walked, according to the Aeon of this world, the ruler of the domain of the air, the spirit who is now at work in the sons of the disobedience;
EPH 2:3 among whom all of us also used to conduct ourselves in the lusts of our flesh, carrying out the desires of the flesh and of the senses, and were by nature children of wrath, just like the rest.
EPH 2:4 But God—being rich in mercy, because of His great love with which He loved us,
EPH 2:5 even when we were dead in our transgressions—made us alive together with Christ (by grace you have been saved)
EPH 2:6 and raised us up together and seated us together in the heavenly realms in Christ Jesus,
EPH 2:7 in order that in the coming ages He might display the surpassing riches of His grace, through His kindness toward us in Christ Jesus.
EPH 2:8 For by grace you have been saved, through the Faith—and this not of yourselves, it is the gift of God—
EPH 2:9 not by works, so that no one may boast.
EPH 2:10 You see, we are His ‘poem’, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared in advance in order that we should walk in them.
EPH 2:11 So then, remember that once you physical Gentiles—called ‘uncircumcision’ by the so-called ‘circumcision’ (that made in flesh with hands)—
EPH 2:12 that at that time you were apart from Christ, excluded from citizenship in Israel and strangers to the covenants of the promise, having no hope and without God in the world.
EPH 2:13 But now in Christ Jesus you who once were far away have come to be near through the blood of the Christ.
EPH 2:14 For He Himself is our peace, who has made both one and broken down the barrier of separation—the law with its commandments and ordinances—
EPH 2:15 having abolished the enmity through His ‘flesh’, so as to mold the two [Jew and Gentile] into one new man in Himself (thus making peace),
EPH 2:16 and to reconcile them both in one body to God through the cross (by which He killed the enmity).
EPH 2:17 He came and proclaimed peace to us, being both far and near,
EPH 2:18 because through Him we both have access to the Father, by one Spirit.
EPH 2:19 So then, you are no longer strangers and aliens, but fellow citizens with the saints and members of God's household,
EPH 2:20 built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ Himself being the chief cornerstone;
EPH 2:21 in whom the whole building, being joined together, grows into a holy temple in the Lord;
EPH 2:22 in whom you also are being built together to become a habitation of God in spirit.
EPH 3:1 For this reason I, Paul, the prisoner of Christ Jesus on behalf of you Gentiles—
EPH 3:2 surely you have heard of the dispensation of the grace of God that was given to me for you,
EPH 3:3 how that by revelation He made known to me the ‘secret’ (as I have written briefly already,
EPH 3:4 with reference to which, when you read, you can understand my insight into Christ's secret),
EPH 3:5 which in different generations was not made known to the sons of men, as it has now been revealed by Spirit to His holy apostles and prophets:
EPH 3:6 that the Gentiles are joint-heirs, of the same body, and fellow partakers of His promise in the Christ through the Gospel,
EPH 3:7 of which I became a servant according to the gift of God's grace, the gift given to me according to the outworking of His power.
EPH 3:8 To me, the very least of all saints, was this grace given, to preach among the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ,
EPH 3:9 and to enlighten all as to the program of the secret that from the beginning of the ages has been hidden by the God who created all things through Jesus Christ;
EPH 3:10 to the intent that now, through the Church, the manifold wisdom of God might be made known to the rulers and the authorities in the heavenly realms,
EPH 3:11 according to the eternal purpose that He accomplished by Christ Jesus our Lord,
EPH 3:12 in whom we have the boldness and the access with confidence through faith in Him.
EPH 3:13 Therefore I ask that you not lose heart at my afflictions on your behalf, which is your glory.
EPH 3:14 For this reason I bow my knees to the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ,
EPH 3:15 from whom every family in heaven and on earth receives its name,
EPH 3:16 that He[F] may grant you, according to the riches of His glory: 1) to be strengthened with power by His Spirit in the inner man;
EPH 3:17 2) Christ to dwell in your hearts through the Faith, having been rooted and established in love
EPH 3:18 so that you may be fully able to grasp (with all saints) what is the breadth and length and depth and height;
EPH 3:19 and 3) to know the love of Christ that surpasses knowledge—so that you may be fulfilled into all the fullness of God.
EPH 3:20 Now to Him who is able to do immeasurably more than all we ask or imagine, according to the power that is working in us,
EPH 3:21 to Him be the glory in the Church in Christ Jesus, to all generations, forever and ever. Amen.
EPH 4:1 So then, as the prisoner in the Lord I urge you to walk worthily of the calling with which you were called,
EPH 4:2 with all humility and courtesy, with patience, bearing with one another in love,
EPH 4:3 taking pains to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of the peace.
EPH 4:4 There is one body and one Spirit (just as you also were called in one hope of your calling),
EPH 4:5 one Lord, one faith, one baptism,
EPH 4:6 one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in us all.
EPH 4:7 Now to each one of us the grace according to the measure of Christ's gift was given.
EPH 4:8 That is why He says, “When He ascended into the heights He captured the concentration camp, and distributed gifts to men.”
EPH 4:9 (What does ‘He ascended’ imply if not that He also first descended into the interior regions of the earth?
EPH 4:10 He who descended is the very one who also ascended far above all the heavens, that He might fill all things.)
EPH 4:11 Yes, He Himself gave some to be apostles, some to be prophets, some to be evangelists, and some to be pastors and teachers,
EPH 4:12 for the equipping of the saints into the work of the ministry, so as to build up the body of Christ,
EPH 4:13 until we all attain into the unity of the faith and of the real knowledge of the Son of God, into a complete man, into the resulting full stature of Christ;
EPH 4:14 so that we no longer be ‘infants’, tossed about as by waves and carried off by every doctrinal fad, through the underhanded dealings of the people who collect the fee for the error;
EPH 4:15 rather, speaking the truth in love, let us in all things grow up into Him who is the Head, the Christ;
EPH 4:16 from whom the whole body, being fitted and knit together by what every joint supplies, as each individual part does its work, promotes its own growth, its own edification, in love.
EPH 4:17 So then, I affirm and insist on this in the Lord: you must no longer carry on as the rest of the Gentiles do, in the futility of their mind,
EPH 4:18 having been darkened in their understanding, being alienated [as a continuing condition] from the life of God, because of the ignorance that is in them due to the hardening of their hearts,
EPH 4:19 who, having become dead to hope, have abandoned themselves to depravity, greedily indulging in every kind of vileness.
EPH 4:20 Now that is not how you ‘learned Christ’—
EPH 4:21 if indeed you have heard Him and been taught by Him (as the truth is in Jesus):
EPH 4:22 that you put away, concerning your former way of life, the old man (that keeps on being corrupted by the deceitful desires),
EPH 4:23 and that you be renewed in the spirit of your mind,
EPH 4:24 and put on the new man, created in the likeness of God, in true righteousness and holiness.
EPH 4:25 Therefore, having put away falsehood, ‘Let each one of you speak truth with his neighbor,’ for we are members of one another.
EPH 4:26 ‘Be angry but do not sin’; do not let the sun set on your angry mood,
EPH 4:27 nor give an opportunity to the devil.
EPH 4:28 The one who steals must steal no longer, but rather let him work, doing something good with his hands, that he may have something to share with someone in need.
EPH 4:29 Let no evil word proceed from your mouth, but only what is good for edification, as needed, that it may impart grace to those who hear.
EPH 4:30 And do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, with whom you were sealed for the day of redemption.
EPH 4:31 Let all bitterness, wrath, anger, clamor and slander be removed from you, with all malice.
EPH 4:32 Rather, be kind to one another, compassionate, forgiving one another, just as in Christ God forgave you.
EPH 5:1 Therefore be imitators of God as beloved children,
EPH 5:2 and walk in love, just as Christ loved us and gave Himself up for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God for a fragrant aroma.
EPH 5:3 But, you should not even talk about fornication or any form of moral corruption or insatiableness (as is fitting for saints);
EPH 5:4 nor any obscenity, nor foolish talk or coarse joking (that do not belong), but rather thanksgiving.
EPH 5:5 Because you can know this for sure: no fornicator, nor anyone who is morally corrupt or insatiable (actually an idolater), has any inheritance in the Kingdom of the Christ and God.
EPH 5:6 Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of these things the wrath of God comes upon the sons of the disobedience.
EPH 5:7 Therefore do not be participants with them
EPH 5:8 —even though you were once darkness, you are now light in Sovereign. Walk as children of light
EPH 5:9 (for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness and righteousness and truth),
EPH 5:10 approving what is pleasing to the Lord.
EPH 5:11 Do not associate with the unfruitful works of the darkness, but rather expose/reprove them.
EPH 5:12 (It is shameful even to speak of those things being done by them in secret.)
EPH 5:13 Now all things, upon being exposed, are revealed by the light, for whatever reveals is light.
EPH 5:14 Therefore He says: “Wake up, O sleeper, and arise from the dead, and the Christ will shine on you.”
EPH 5:15 See then that you walk carefully, not as unwise but as wise,
EPH 5:16 redeeming the time, because the days are evil.
EPH 5:17 That is why you must not be foolish, but understand what the Lord's will is.
EPH 5:18 And do not get drunk on wine, which is harmful and wasteful; rather be filled with the Spirit,
EPH 5:19 speaking to one another with psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making music in your hearts to the Lord;
EPH 5:20 always giving thanks to God the Father concerning all things, in the name of our Lord, Jesus Christ,
EPH 5:21 submitting to one another in the fear of God.
EPH 5:22 Wives, subordinate yourselves to your own husbands, as to the Lord,
EPH 5:23 because a man is head of his wife as also Christ is Head of the Church—He also is Preserver of the body.
EPH 5:24 Yes, just as the Church is subject to Christ, so also the wives should be to their own husbands in everything.
EPH 5:25 Husbands, love your own wives just as Christ also loved the Church and gave Himself up on her behalf,
EPH 5:26 in order that He might sanctify her, having cleansed her by the washing of the water: in a word,
EPH 5:27 that He might present her—the splendid Church—to Himself, not having a blemish or a wrinkle or any such thing, but that she be holy and blameless.
EPH 5:28 Just so the husbands ought to love their own wives as their own bodies; he who loves his wife loves himself.
EPH 5:29 After all, no one ever hated his own flesh; rather he nourishes and cherishes it, just as the Lord does the Church
EPH 5:30 —for we are members of His body, of His flesh and of His bones.
EPH 5:31 “For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and the two will become one flesh.”
EPH 5:32 This is a great mystery, but I speak concerning Christ and the Church.
EPH 5:33 In any case, each of you individually: let each one love his own wife as himself, while the wife must respect her husband.
EPH 6:1 Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right.
EPH 6:2 “Honor your father and mother”—which is the first commandment with a promise—
EPH 6:3 “that it may go well with you and you may live long on the earth.”
EPH 6:4 And fathers, do not provoke your children to anger, but nurture them in the discipline and instruction of Sovereign.
EPH 6:5 Slaves, obey your human masters with fear and trembling, in sincerity of heart, as to Christ;
EPH 6:6 not only when being watched, to please men, but as slaves of the Christ, doing the will of God from the heart;
EPH 6:7 serving with a good attitude, as to the Lord and not to men,
EPH 6:8 knowing that whatever good each one does, he will receive the same again from the Lord, whether he is slave or free.
EPH 6:9 And masters, be the same way towards them, giving up threatening, knowing that your own Master is in heaven, and there is no partiality with Him.
EPH 6:10 Finally, my brothers, be strong in the Lord and in His mighty power.
EPH 6:11 Put on the full armor of God so as to be able to stand firm against the stratagems of the devil.
EPH 6:12 Because, our wrestling match is not against flesh and blood, but against the principalities, against the authorities, against the world-rulers of the darkness of this age, against the malignant spirits in the heavenly realms.
EPH 6:13 That is why you must take up the full armor of God, so that you may be able to resist in the evil day, to stand firm, with everything in place.
EPH 6:14 So stand firm, having belted your waist with truth, having put on the breastplate of righteousness,
EPH 6:15 and having shod your feet with the readiness of the Gospel of the peace;
EPH 6:16 above all, having taken up the shield of the faith, with which you will be able to quench all the flaming arrows of the malignant one;
EPH 6:17 also, grasp the helmet of the salvation and the sword of the Spirit, which is God's Word spoken;
EPH 6:18 praying at all times in the Spirit, using every prayer and petition, yes being watchful to this end with all perseverance and petition for all the saints
EPH 6:19 —on my behalf too, that when I open my mouth utterance may be given to me with boldness, to make known the mystery of the Gospel,
EPH 6:20 for which I am an ambassador in chains; that I may declare it boldly, as I ought to do.
EPH 6:21 Now that you also may know my affairs, how I am doing, Tychicus, the dear brother and faithful servant in the Lord, will tell you everything;
EPH 6:22 whom I have sent to you for this very purpose: that you may know our circumstances and that he may comfort your hearts.
EPH 6:23 Peace be to the brothers, and love with faith, from God the Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
EPH 6:24 The grace be with all those who love our Lord Jesus Christ with an undying love. Amen.
PHI 1:1 Paul and Timothy, slaves of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus who are at Philippi, together with the overseers and deacons:
PHI 1:2 Grace to you and peace from God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
PHI 1:3 I thank my God every time I remember you;
PHI 1:4 in all my prayers for all of you I always pray with joy,
PHI 1:5 because of your partnership in the Gospel from the first day until now,
PHI 1:6 being certain of this very thing, that He who began a good work in you will complete it until the Day of Jesus Christ;
PHI 1:7 just as it is right for me to think this of you all, because I have you in my heart, inasmuch as both in my chains and in the defense and confirmation of the Gospel you all are partakers with me of the Grace.
PHI 1:8 God is my witness how I long for you all with the affection of Jesus Christ.
PHI 1:9 This is what I pray: that your love may abound yet more and more in real knowledge and full discernment,
PHI 1:10 for you to identify the things that really matter; that you may be sincere and blameless until the Day of Christ,
PHI 1:11 having been filled with the fruits of righteousness that are through Jesus Christ, to the glory and praise of God.
PHI 1:12 Now I want you to know, brothers, that the events against me have actually turned out for the advancement of the Gospel:
PHI 1:13 as a result, it has become evident to the whole imperial guard, and to everyone else, that I am in chains for Christ;
PHI 1:14 also, most of the brothers in Sovereign have been influenced by my chains to be much bolder, to speak the Word fearlessly.
PHI 1:15 To be sure, some are even preaching Christ out of envy and rivalry, but others out of good will;
PHI 1:16 the former proclaim Christ out of selfish ambition, not sincerely, thinking to add to my affliction while in chains,
PHI 1:17 but the latter out of love, knowing that I am set here for the defense of the Gospel.
PHI 1:18 No problem: in every way, be it in pretense or in truth, Christ is proclaimed, and in this I rejoice—yes, and will rejoice.
PHI 1:19 You see, I know that this will turn out for my deliverance (through your supplication and the support of the Spirit of Jesus Christ)
PHI 1:20 according to my earnest expectation and hope that I will not be put to shame in anything but be truly bold, so that now as always Christ will be glorified in my person, whether by life or by death
PHI 1:21 —to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain.
PHI 1:22 Now if I am to live on in the flesh it will mean fruitful labor for me, so I do not know what to choose.
PHI 1:23 I am torn between the two: I have the desire to depart and be with Christ (far better),
PHI 1:24 but to remain in the flesh is more necessary, because of you.
PHI 1:25 So having been persuaded of this, I know that I will remain and continue with you all for your progress and joy in the faith,
PHI 1:26 so that your rejoicing over me may be more abundant in Christ Jesus, through my coming to you again.
PHI 1:27 Only conduct yourselves in a manner worthy of the Gospel of Christ, so that whether I come and see you, or am absent, I may hear about you that you stand firm in one spirit, striving together for the faith of the Gospel with one soul,
PHI 1:28 and not being intimidated in any way by your opponents: to them this is an indicator of ruin, but to you of deliverance, and that from God.
PHI 1:29 For it has been granted to you on behalf of Christ not only to believe into Him, but also to suffer for His sake,
PHI 1:30 having the same struggle that you saw in me and now hear to be in me.
PHI 2:1 Therefore, if there is any encouragement in Christ, if any comfort of love, if any fellowship from the Spirit, if any tenderness and acts of compassion,
PHI 2:2 make my joy full by being like-minded, having the same love, being one in spirit and purpose.
PHI 2:3 Do nothing out of selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility regard one another as being better than yourselves.
PHI 2:4 Let each of you look out not only for his own concerns, but also for what concerns others.
PHI 2:5 In fact, let this mindset be in you that was also in Christ Jesus,
PHI 2:6 who, existing in God's form, did not consider equality with God a thing to be grasped,
PHI 2:7 but divested Himself, taking a slave's form, coming to be in the likeness of men.
PHI 2:8 And being found in appearance as a man, He humbled Himself, becoming obedient to the point of death—even death on a cross!
PHI 2:9 Indeed, that is why God highly exalted Him and gave Him the name that is above every name,
PHI 2:10 so that at the name of Jesus every knee will bow—of those in heaven, those on earth and those under the earth—
PHI 2:11 and every tongue will acknowledge that Jesus Christ is Sovereign, to the glory of God the Father.
PHI 2:12 So then, my dear ones, just as you have always obeyed (not only in my presence but now much more in my absence), keep working out your own salvation with fear and trembling,
PHI 2:13 because God Himself is the One at work in you, both to will and to produce, for His good pleasure.
PHI 2:14 Do all things without grumbling or arguing,
PHI 2:15 so that you may become blameless and pure, children of God without fault in the midst of a crooked and depraved generation, among whom you shine as light bearers in the world,
PHI 2:16 holding fast the Word of Life, so that I may rejoice in the day of Christ that I did not run in vain nor labor for nothing.
PHI 2:17 Yes, even if I am a libation being poured on the sacrifice and service of your faith, I am glad and rejoice with all of you.
PHI 2:18 For the same reason you also be glad and rejoice with me.
PHI 2:19 Now I hope in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you soon, that I also may be encouraged when I know how you are doing.
PHI 2:20 For I have no one else like-minded, who will be genuinely concerned about your welfare
PHI 2:21 (for all seek their own interests, not those of Christ Jesus).
PHI 2:22 But you know the proof of him, that as a son with his father he slaved with me for the Gospel.
PHI 2:23 Therefore I hope to send him at once, as soon as I see how things go with me.
PHI 2:24 Still, I am confident in the Lord that I myself will come soon.
PHI 2:25 However, I considered it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother, fellow worker and fellow soldier; also your messenger and minister to my need;
PHI 2:26 since he was longing for you all, and was distressed because you had heard that he was sick.
PHI 2:27 Well, he really was sick, nearly to death, but God had mercy on him, and not only on him but also on me, that I might not have sorrow upon sorrow.
PHI 2:28 So I sent him the more eagerly, that upon seeing him you might have joy, and I be less anxious.
PHI 2:29 Receive him in Sovereign with great joy, and hold such men in honor,
PHI 2:30 because for the work of the Christ he came close to death, not regarding his life, to complete what was lacking in your service toward me.
PHI 3:1 Finally, my brothers, rejoice in Sovereign. For me to write the same things to you is not troublesome and for you it is the safe thing.
PHI 3:2 Watch out for the ‘dogs’, watch out for the bad workers, watch out for the mutilation!
PHI 3:3 For it is we who are the circumcision, the ones who worship by God's Spirit and glory in Christ Jesus, and who put no confidence in flesh
PHI 3:4 (though I myself actually have basis for such confidence). If anyone else thinks he has basis for confidence in flesh, I even more:
PHI 3:5 circumcised the eighth day, of the nation of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of the Hebrews; with respect to the Law, a Pharisee;
PHI 3:6 with respect to zeal, persecuting the Church; with respect to the righteousness that is in the law, blameless.
PHI 3:7 But such things as were gain to me, these I have considered loss for the sake of the Christ.
PHI 3:8 Yes indeed, in fact I actually consider everything to be a loss for the sake of the excelling thing, the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord—for His sake I have already lost everything (and consider it as trash), so that I may gain Christ
PHI 3:9 and be found in Him, not having as my righteousness that of the Law but that which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness of God based on that faith;
PHI 3:10 so that I may know Him and the power of His resurrection, and the sharing in His sufferings, becoming like Him in His death,
PHI 3:11 and so, somehow, that I may arrive into the resurrection from among the dead
PHI 3:12 —not that I have already obtained it or have already been perfected; but I press on to actually claim that for which Christ Jesus claimed me.
PHI 3:13 Brothers, I do not consider that I have already claimed it, but this: forgetting the things behind and straining toward those ahead,
PHI 3:14 I press on toward the goal for the prize, the upward call from God because of Christ Jesus.
PHI 3:15 So then, those of us who are mature should have this mentality, but if on some point you think differently, God will reveal that to you as well.
PHI 3:16 Only, in what we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule, let us be of the same mind.
PHI 3:17 Brothers, join together in imitating me, and having us as a pattern take note of those who walk in the same way.
PHI 3:18 Because many are walking as enemies of the cross of Christ—of whom I told you often, and now tell you even with tears—
PHI 3:19 whose end is ruin, whose god is their stomach, and whose glory is in their shame; their mind is only on earthly things.
PHI 3:20 But our citizenship is in Heaven, and it is from there that we eagerly await our Deliverer, Sovereign Jesus Christ;
PHI 3:21 who will transform the body of our humiliation so that it will be conformed to the body of His glory, according to the working by which He is indeed able to subject all things to Himself.
PHI 4:1 So then, my brothers, beloved and longed for, my joy and crown, do stand fast in Sovereign in this way, dear ones.
PHI 4:2 I urge Euodia and I urge Syntyche to come to agreement in the Lord.
PHI 4:3 Yes, I urge you too, genuine yokefellow, help these women who labored with me in the Gospel, and with Clement and the rest of my fellow workers, whose names are in the Book of Life.
PHI 4:4 Rejoice in Sovereign always; again I say, rejoice!
PHI 4:5 Let your forbearing spirit be evident to all; the Lord is near.
PHI 4:6 Do not be anxious about anything, but in everything, by prayer and petition along with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God;
PHI 4:7 and the peace of God, that surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
PHI 4:8 Finally, brothers, whatever things are true, whatever things are honorable, whatever things are just, whatever things are pure, whatever things are lovely, whatever things are commendable—whatever is of excellent character and whatever is praiseworthy—ponder such things.
PHI 4:9 Put into practice the things that you learned, received, heard and saw in me, and the God of peace will be with you.
PHI 4:10 I rejoice in the Lord greatly that you have renewed your concern for me once again; of course you were concerned, just lacked the opportunity.
PHI 4:11 I am not saying this because of lack, since I have learned to be content whatever the circumstances.
PHI 4:12 I know what it is to be restricted, and I know what it is to have an abundance; everywhere and in every way I have been initiated both into being well fed and into being hungry, both into having plenty and into having need.
PHI 4:13 I can handle anything through Christ who strengthens me.
PHI 4:14 Nevertheless you have done well in sharing with me in my trial.
PHI 4:15 Now you Philippians know very well that in the beginning of the Gospel, when I left Macedonia, no congregation shared with me in the matter of giving and receiving but you only.
PHI 4:16 Yes, even in Thessalonica, both once and again, you sent aid for my need.
PHI 4:17 Not that I want the gift, but I want the fruit that is being added to your account.
PHI 4:18 I have received everything and have plenty; I am well supplied, having received from Epaphroditus the things you sent, a fragrant aroma, an acceptable sacrifice, well pleasing to God.
PHI 4:19 My God will supply every need of yours according to His riches in glory in Christ Jesus.
PHI 4:20 Now to our God and Father be the glory for ever and ever. Amen.
PHI 4:21 Greet every saint in Christ Jesus. The brothers who are with me greet you.
PHI 4:22 All the saints greet you, but especially those who are of Caesar's household.
PHI 4:23 The grace of the Sovereign, Jesus Christ, be with you all. Amen.
COL 1:1 Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and brother Timothy,
COL 1:2 to the holy and faithful brothers in Christ at Colosse: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
COL 1:3 We always give thanks to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ when we pray for you
COL 1:4 (having heard of your faith in Christ Jesus and your love toward all the saints),
COL 1:5 because of the hope that is being reserved for you in the heavens, of which you have already heard through the Word of the Truth
COL 1:6 (the Gospel that has come to you just as also in all the world, where it is producing fruit and growing just as also among you, from the day in which you heard about and truly understood God's grace),
COL 1:7 even as you learned from Epaphras, our dear fellow slave, who is a faithful servant of Christ on your behalf,
COL 1:8 who also reported to us your love in spirit.
COL 1:9 For this very reason, since the day we heard of it, we have not stopped praying for you and asking that you may be filled with the real knowledge of His will in all wisdom and spiritual understanding,
COL 1:10 in order for you to walk worthily of the Lord, pleasing Him in every way, being fruitful in every good work and growing into the real knowledge of God;
COL 1:11 being enabled with all capability according to the strength that resides in His glory, for all endurance and steadfastness.
COL 1:12 Nor have we stopped giving thanks joyfully to the Father who has qualified us for the share in the inheritance of the saints in the Light;
COL 1:13 who delivered us out of the dominion of the darkness and transferred us into the kingdom of the Son of His love,
COL 1:14 in whom we have the redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of our sins.
COL 1:15 He is the visible representation of the invisible God, ‘Firstborn’ over all creation,
COL 1:16 because by Him all things were created—those in the heavens and those on the earth, things visible and things invisible, whether thrones or dominions or rulers or authorities—all things have been created through Him and for Him.
COL 1:17 Yes, He is before all, and in Him all things subsist.
COL 1:18 Also, He is the Head of the body, the Church. He is Beginning, the firstborn from among the dead, so that He may be preeminent in everything,
COL 1:19 because in Him all the Fullness was pleased to dwell
COL 1:20 and through Him to reconcile all things to Himself, having made peace through the blood of His cross—through Him, whether things on the earth or things on the heavens.
COL 1:21 So now He has reconciled you as well (you who once were alienated and hostile in your mind because of your wicked works),
COL 1:22 by His physical body through His death, so as to present you before Him holy and blameless and above reproach—
COL 1:23 if, that is, you continue in the Faith established and firm, not drifting away from the hope of the Gospel, that you heard and that was proclaimed in all the creation under the heaven, of which I, Paul, became a servant.
COL 1:24 Now I rejoice in my sufferings on your behalf and supplement in my flesh the things lacking in the afflictions of Christ, for the sake of His body, which is the Church,
COL 1:25 of which I became a servant according to the stewardship from God that was given to me towards you, to complete the Word of God,
COL 1:26 the secret that has been hidden from past ages and generations, but now has been revealed to His saints;
COL 1:27 to whom God resolved to make known who is the wealth of the glory of this secret among the nations, namely Christ in you, the hope of glory;
COL 1:28 whom we proclaim, warning every man and teaching every man with all wisdom, that we may present every man perfect in Christ.
COL 1:29 It is to this end that I labor, striving according to His working that works through me with power.
COL 2:1 I want you to know how great is my concern for you and those in Laodicea, even all who have not met me personally,
COL 2:2 that their hearts may be encouraged, being united in love and into a great wealth of confident understanding, into a real knowledge of the mystery of the God and Father and of the Christ,
COL 2:3 in whom all the treasures of the wisdom and the knowledge are hidden.
COL 2:4 Now I say this so that no one may deceive you with specious arguments.
COL 2:5 For although in fact I am physically absent, yet my spirit is with you, rejoicing as I observe your orderliness and the firmness of your faith in Christ.
COL 2:6 So then, keep on walking in the Christ, Jesus the Sovereign, just as you received Him,
COL 2:7 having been rooted and being built up in Him and being established in the faith, just as you were taught, abounding in it with thanksgiving.
COL 2:8 Be careful that no one captures you through philosophy and empty deceit, according to human tradition, according to the basic principles of the world and not according to Christ.
COL 2:9 Because all the Fullness of the Godhead dwells in Him in bodily form,
COL 2:10 and you are complete in Him who is the head over all rule and authority.
COL 2:11 In Him you were also ‘circumcised’ by the putting off of the body of the sins of the flesh, not with a circumcision done by hands but with the circumcision of the Christ,
COL 2:12 having been buried with Him in the baptism. In Him you were also raised together through your faith in the productive power of the God who raised Him from among the dead.
COL 2:13 Yes you, though being dead in your trespasses and the uncircumcision of your flesh—He has made you alive together with Him; having forgiven us all our trespasses;
COL 2:14 having wiped out the written record about us that was against us (based on the ordinances), indeed He has taken it out of the way, having nailed it to the cross;
COL 2:15 having stripped the principalities and the authorities, He made a public spectacle of them, having triumphed over them by it [the cross].
COL 2:16 So do not let anyone judge you about food or drink, or with respect to a feast day or a new moon or Sabbaths,
COL 2:17 which things are but a shadow of those to come, while the body is Christ's.
COL 2:18 Nor let anyone disqualify you, taking pleasure in a subservience and devotion to the angels, ‘taking possession’ of things that he has not seen, being puffed up by his carnal mind to no useful purpose,
