COL 2:19 and not holding fast to the Head, from whom all the body, supported and held together by its joints and ligaments, grows with the increase that is from God.
COL 2:20 Now then, since you died with Christ away from the basic principles of the world, why, as though still living in it, are you subjecting yourselves to regulations
COL 2:21 —Don't handle! Don't taste! Don't touch!—
COL 2:22 (all of which result in corruption through overuse) according to the commands and teachings of men?
COL 2:23 Such things do indeed have an appearance of wisdom in self-made religion and subservience and asceticism, but are not of any value against the indulgence of the flesh.
COL 3:1 Furthermore, since you were raised together with Christ, seek the things that are above, where Christ is, sitting at God's right;
COL 3:2 set your mind on the things above, not on those upon the earth,
COL 3:3 because you died and your life has been hidden with Christ in God.
COL 3:4 Whenever Christ, our life, is revealed, then you also will be revealed with Him in glory.
COL 3:5 Therefore put to death your members that are on the earth: fornication, filthiness, passion, evil desire, and the greediness that is idolatry.
COL 3:6 Because of these things the wrath of God is coming upon the sons of the disobedience,
COL 3:7 in which things you yourselves once walked when you lived in them.
COL 3:8 But now you must also rid yourselves of all these—anger, rage, malice, slander, obscene speech—out of your mouth.
COL 3:9 Do not lie to one another, since you have taken off the old man with his practices
COL 3:10 and have put on the new one, who is being renewed into real knowledge according to the image of his Creator,
COL 3:11 where there is neither Greek nor Jew, circumcision nor uncircumcision, barbarian, Scythian, slave, free; but Christ is all and in all.
COL 3:12 Therefore, as God's chosen ones, holy and beloved, put on hearts of compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, patience;
COL 3:13 bearing with one another and forgiving each other, if anyone should have a complaint against another—just as the Christ forgave you, so you also must do.
COL 3:14 And above all these things put on love, which is the bond of perfection.
COL 3:15 Let the peace of God rule in your hearts, into which also you were called in one body; and be thankful.
COL 3:16 Let the Word of Christ dwell in you richly as you teach and admonish one another with all wisdom, and as you sing with grace in your heart to the Lord, with psalms and hymns and spiritual songs.
COL 3:17 Whatever you may do in word or deed, do all in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through Him.
COL 3:18 Wives, subordinate yourselves to your own husbands, as is fitting in the Lord.
COL 3:19 Husbands, love your wives and do not be embittered against them.
COL 3:20 Children, obey your parents in everything, because this is well pleasing in the Lord.
COL 3:21 Fathers, do not provoke your children so that they lose heart.
COL 3:22 Slaves, obey your masters (according to the flesh) in all things, not just when they are looking, as men-pleasers, but in sincerity of heart, fearing God.
COL 3:23 And whatever you do, give it all you've got, as to the Lord and not to men,
COL 3:24 knowing that it is from the Lord that you will receive the inheritance as a reward; because you serve the Lord Christ.
COL 3:25 (But he who does wrong will be repaid for this wrong, and there is no favoritism.)
COL 4:1 Masters, provide your slaves with what is just and fair, knowing that you also have a Master in the heavens.
COL 4:2 Continue earnestly in prayer, being vigilant in it with thanksgiving,
COL 4:3 at the same time praying for us, that God may open to us a door for the Word, to speak the mystery of Christ (for which I am also in chains),
COL 4:4 that I may make it manifest, as I ought to speak.
COL 4:5 Behave wisely toward outsiders, making the most of the opportunity.
COL 4:6 Let your word always be with grace, seasoned with salt, to know how you ought to answer each one.
COL 4:7 Tychicus will tell you all the news about me; he is a dear brother, a faithful minister and fellow slave in the Lord.
COL 4:8 I am sending him to you for this very purpose, that he may know your circumstances and encourage your hearts,
COL 4:9 with Onesimus, a faithful and beloved brother, who is one of you; they will tell you everything that is happening here.
COL 4:10 Aristarchus my fellow prisoner greets you, as does Mark the cousin of Barnabas (about whom you received instructions; if he comes to you, welcome him),
COL 4:11 and Jesus who is called Justus. These are my only fellow workers for the Kingdom of God who are of the circumcision; they have been a comfort to me.
COL 4:12 Epaphras, who is one of you, a slave of Christ, greets you; he is always wrestling in prayer for you, that you may stand perfect and complete in all the will of God.
COL 4:13 I bear him witness that he has a great zeal for you, and for those in Laodicea and those in Hierapolis.
COL 4:14 Luke the beloved physician greets you, also Demas.
COL 4:15 Greet the brothers who are in Laodicea, and Nymphas and the congregation at his house.
COL 4:16 Now when this letter has been read among you, see that it is also read in the Laodicean congregation, and that you in turn read the letter from Laodicea.
COL 4:17 And say to Archippus, “See to it that you complete the work that you received in the Lord.”
COL 4:18 This greeting is in my own hand: Paul. Remember my chains. The Grace be with you. Amen.
1TH 1:1 Paul, Silvanus and Timothy, to the congregation of Thessalonians in God the Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
1TH 1:2 We always give thanks to God for all of you, making mention of you in our prayers,
1TH 1:3 continually remembering before our God and Father your work for the Faith and your labor coming from the Love and your perseverance based on the Hope, our Lord Jesus Christ being their source,
1TH 1:4 knowing as we do, brothers loved by God, that you are chosen.
1TH 1:5 You see, our Gospel did not come to you in word only, but also in power and in the Holy Spirit and with complete certainty (of course you know what sort of men we proved to be among you for your sake).
1TH 1:6 Yes you became imitators of us and of the Lord, having received the Word with the Holy Spirit's joy, in spite of severe affliction,
1TH 1:7 so that you became examples to all the believers in Macedonia and Achaia.
1TH 1:8 That is because the Word of the Lord sounded out from you, not only in Macedonia and Achaia but also in every place—your faith toward God has gone forth, so that we do not need to say anything.
1TH 1:9 They themselves report about you what kind of entrance we had to you, and how you turned to God from idols to be slaves to the living and true God,
1TH 1:10 and to wait for His Son coming out of the heavens (whom He raised from among the dead)—Jesus, who preserves us from the coming wrath.
1TH 2:1 Now you yourselves know, brothers, that our entrance to you did not happen without purpose.
1TH 2:2 Rather, in spite of having already suffered and been insulted in Philippi, as you know, we made bold in our God to speak to you the Gospel of God, in the face of strong opposition.
1TH 2:3 Further, our exhortation does not spring from delusion or impurity, nor is it in deception,
1TH 2:4 but we speak precisely as those who have been approved by God to be entrusted with the Gospel, not so as to please men, but to please the God who evaluates our hearts.
1TH 2:5 Further, you well know that we never used words to flatter, or to disguise greed (God is witness),
1TH 2:6 or to seek glory from men (whether from you or from others)—as apostles of Christ we could have been ‘heavy’,
1TH 2:7 but we were gentle among you, like a nurse cherishing her own children.
1TH 2:8 Yearning over you in this way, we were well pleased to share with you not only the Gospel of God but also our own selves, because you had become dear to us.
1TH 2:9 Surely you remember, brothers, our toil and exertion, because working night and day, so as not to burden any of you, we proclaimed the Gospel of God to you.
1TH 2:10 You are witnesses, and so is God, how devoutly and justly and blamelessly we behaved ourselves among you who believe;
1TH 2:11 indeed, you know how we treated each one of you as a father does his own children, exhorting and comforting you,
1TH 2:12 insisting that you conduct yourselves in a manner worthy of the God who calls you into His own kingdom and glory.
1TH 2:13 Another reason we give thanks to God continually is that when you received from us the spoken Word of God, you welcomed it not as the word of men but, as it actually is, the Word of God, which is indeed operative in you who believe.
1TH 2:14 For you, brothers, became imitators of God's congregations in Christ Jesus, the ones in Judea, in that you also suffered the same things from your own countrymen that they did from the Jews
1TH 2:15 (the ones who killed both the Lord Jesus and their own prophets, who have persecuted us, who do not please God and are hostile to everybody,
1TH 2:16 trying to prevent us from speaking to the Gentiles so that they may be saved—so as to fill up the measure of their sins. They have received the full impact of the Wrath).
1TH 2:17 Now we, brothers, having been bereaved of you for a short season (in presence, not in heart), made every effort to see your face, from intense longing.
1TH 2:18 (We actually tried to come to you—I, Paul, time and again—but Satan thwarted us.)
1TH 2:19 For what is our hope, or joy, or crown of glorying? Is it not precisely you, in the presence of our Lord Jesus at His coming?
1TH 2:20 Indeed, you are our glory and our joy.
1TH 3:1 So when we could not stand it any longer, we thought it good to be left in Athens alone
1TH 3:2 and sent Timothy, our brother and minister of God, also our fellow worker in the Gospel of Christ, to confirm you and encourage you concerning your faith,
1TH 3:3 that no one be unsettled by these afflictions; for you yourselves know that we are appointed to this.
1TH 3:4 For indeed, when we were with you we kept telling you in advance that we were going to be afflicted; just as it happened, in fact, as you know.
1TH 3:5 Yes, that is why, no longer standing it, I sent to find out about your faith, for fear that somehow the tempter had successfully tempted you and our labor come to be for nothing.
1TH 3:6 But now that Timothy has come to us from you and brought us glad news of your faith and love, and that you have good memories of us always, longing to see us, just as we also long to see you
1TH 3:7 —because of this, brothers, in all our affliction and distress we were encouraged about you by your faith;
1TH 3:8 for now we live, if you are standing firm in the Lord.
1TH 3:9 With what thankfulness can we repay God for you, for all the joy with which we are rejoicing in the presence of our God because of you;
1TH 3:10 praying most earnestly night and day, that we may see your face and complete the things lacking in your faith?
1TH 3:11 Now may our God and Father Himself and our Lord Jesus Christ direct our way to you.
1TH 3:12 And may the Lord cause you to increase and abound in love toward each other and toward all, just as we also do toward you,
1TH 3:13 so as to establish your hearts blameless in holiness before our God and Father at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ with all His holy ones.
1TH 4:1 Finally then, brothers, we urge and exhort you in the Lord Jesus: as you received from us how you ought to behave and please God, do so even more
1TH 4:2 —you know what instructions we gave you through Sovereign Jesus.
1TH 4:3 Now this is the will of God, your sanctification: that you stay away from fornication;
1TH 4:4 that each of you know how to gain possession of his own ‘vessel’ in sanctification and honor,
1TH 4:5 not in lustful passion (like the heathen who do not know God);
1TH 4:6 that no one trespass and defraud his brother in this matter, because the Lord is the avenger of all such behavior, as, indeed, we have already told you and warned you.
1TH 4:7 Because God did not call us for uncleanness, but by holiness.
1TH 4:8 So then, the rejecter is not rejecting man, but God, the very One who gave you His Holy Spirit.
1TH 4:9 Now about brotherly love you do not need to be written to, for you yourselves are taught by God to love one another,
1TH 4:10 because in fact you are doing so toward all the brothers throughout Macedonia. Still, we exhort you to do even more, brothers,
1TH 4:11 to make it a point to be peaceable and to mind your own business, to work with your hands (as we instructed you),
1TH 4:12 so that outsiders may be well impressed by your life style, and that you may have no lack.
1TH 4:13 Now then, brothers, we do not want you to be ignorant about those who have ‘fallen asleep’, so that you do not grieve like the rest, who have no hope.
1TH 4:14 Because since we believe that Jesus died and rose again, just so will God bring with Jesus those who have fallen asleep in Him.
1TH 4:15 For this we say to you by a word of the Lord, that we who are still alive, who are left until the coming of the Lord, will absolutely not precede those who have fallen asleep;
1TH 4:16 because the Lord Himself—with a commanding shout, with the archangel's voice and with God's trumpet—will come down from heaven, and the dead in Christ will rise first;
1TH 4:17 then we who are still alive, who are left, will be snatched up together with them in clouds to meet the Lord in the air. In precisely this way we will always be with the Lord.
1TH 4:18 So then, comfort one another with these words.
1TH 5:1 Now concerning the times and the seasons, brothers, you do not need to be written to,
1TH 5:2 for you yourselves know very well that the Day of the Lord comes just like a thief in the night.
1TH 5:3 For whenever they say, “Peace and safety!” then sudden destruction is standing near them, like labor pains to a pregnant woman, and they will not escape.
1TH 5:4 But you, brothers, are not in darkness so that this Day should come upon you like a thief.
1TH 5:5 You are all sons of light and sons of day; we are not of night, nor of darkness.
1TH 5:6 So then, let us not sleep, like the rest, but let us stay alert and sober;
1TH 5:7 because those who sleep, sleep at night, and those who get drunk, get drunk at night;
1TH 5:8 but we being of day, let us be sober, putting on a breastplate of faith and love, and a helmet of hope of salvation.
1TH 5:9 For God did not appoint us to undergo wrath but to obtain salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ,
1TH 5:10 who died for us so that whether awake or asleep we may live together with Him.
1TH 5:11 Therefore encourage one another and build each other up, as in fact you do.
1TH 5:12 Now we urge you, brothers, to recognize those who labor among you and are over you in the Lord and admonish you,
1TH 5:13 and to esteem them very highly in love because of their work. Be at peace among yourselves.
1TH 5:14 Now we exhort you, brothers: admonish the disorderly, encourage the fainthearted, be supportive of the weak, be patient toward all.
1TH 5:15 See that no one pays back bad for bad to anyone, but always pursue the good, both for one another and for all.
1TH 5:16 Rejoice always!
1TH 5:17 Pray continually!
1TH 5:18 Give thanks in everything, for this is God's will for you in Christ Jesus.
1TH 5:19 Do not quench the Spirit!
1TH 5:20 Do not disdain prophesies,
1TH 5:21 but test everything; hold on to the good.
1TH 5:22 Keep away from every form of evil!
1TH 5:23 Now may the God of peace Himself sanctify you completely, and may your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameless at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
1TH 5:24 He who calls you is faithful, and He will do it.
1TH 5:25 Brothers, pray for us.
1TH 5:26 Greet all the brothers with a holy kiss.
1TH 5:27 I adjure you by the Lord that this letter be read to all the holy brothers.
1TH 5:28 The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. Amen.
2TH 1:1 Paul, Silvanus and Timothy, to the congregation of the Thessalonians in God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ:
2TH 1:2 Grace and peace to you from God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
2TH 1:3 We are obligated to always give thanks to God about you, brothers, and properly so, because your faith is really growing, and the love of each and every one of you towards each other keeps increasing;
2TH 1:4 so that we ourselves boast about you among God's congregations, referring to your steadfastness and faith in the midst of all your persecutions, and the tribulations that you are enduring
2TH 1:5 —the above is evidence that God's judgment is right, to the end that you be considered worthy of the Kingdom of God, on behalf of which you are actually suffering;
2TH 1:6 since to God it is right to pay back affliction to those who are afflicting you
2TH 1:7 and rest (along with us) to you who are being afflicted, at the revelation of the Lord Jesus from heaven with His powerful angels in blazing fire,
2TH 1:8 inflicting vengeance on those who do not know God and on those who do not obey the Gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ,
2TH 1:9 who will pay a penalty: everlasting ruin, away from the face of the Lord and from the glory of His might,
2TH 1:10 whenever He comes to be glorified by His saints, yes to be marveled at by all who have believed (because our testimony to you was believed); in that Day.
2TH 1:11 To this end we also pray always for you, that our God may count you worthy of the calling and fulfill with power every desire of usefulness and work of faith,
2TH 1:12 so that the name of our Lord Jesus Christ may be glorified in you, and you in Him, according to the grace of our God and Lord, Jesus Christ.
2TH 2:1 Now, brothers, concerning the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our being gathered to Him, we urge you
2TH 2:2 not to be quickly shaken from your conviction or disturbed, whether by a spirit or a word or a letter as from us, as though the Day of Christ has come.
2TH 2:3 Do not let anyone deceive you by any means; because that day cannot come unless the rebellion comes first and the man of sin is revealed, the son of ruin,
2TH 2:4 who opposes and exalts himself over everything that is called a god or an object of worship, to the point of taking his seat as God in God's sanctuary, proclaiming himself to be God.
2TH 2:5 (Don't you remember that I used to tell you these things while still with you?)
2TH 2:6 So now you know what is restraining, to the end that he may be revealed at his own time.
2TH 2:7 For the mystery of the lawlessness is already at work; only He who now restrains will do so until He removes Himself.
2TH 2:8 And then the lawless one will be revealed, whom the Lord will consume with the breath of His mouth and abolish by the splendor of His coming;
2TH 2:9 that one's coming is according to the working of Satan with all power and signs and lying wonders,
2TH 2:10 and with all wicked deception among those who are wasting themselves, because they did not receive the love of the truth so that they might be saved.
2TH 2:11 Yes, because of this God will send them an active delusion so that they will believe the lie
2TH 2:12 and so that all may be condemned who have not believed the truth but have taken pleasure in wickedness.
2TH 2:13 Now we are obligated to always give thanks to God about you, brothers loved by the Lord, because from the beginning God chose you into salvation, through sanctification of spirit and belief in truth,
2TH 2:14 to which He called you through our gospel, so as to obtain the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ.
2TH 2:15 So then, brothers, stand firm and hold to the traditions that you were taught by us, whether by word or by letter.
2TH 2:16 Now may our Lord Jesus Christ Himself, and our God and Father, who loved us and gave us eternal comfort and good hope, by grace,
2TH 2:17 encourage your hearts and strengthen you in every good word and work.
2TH 3:1 Finally, brothers, pray for us, that the word of the Lord may spread rapidly and be glorified, as also with you,
2TH 3:2 and that we may be delivered from evil and malignant men; for not all have faith.
2TH 3:3 But the Lord is faithful, who will strengthen you and guard you from the malignant one.
2TH 3:4 We have confidence in the Lord concerning you, that you both do and will do the things we command.
2TH 3:5 Now may the Lord direct your hearts into the love of God and into the perseverance of Christ.
2TH 3:6 Now we command you, brothers, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you withdraw from every brother who behaves irresponsibly and not according to the tradition that they received from us.
2TH 3:7 For you yourselves know how you ought to imitate us, because we did not behave irresponsibly among you;
2TH 3:8 neither did we eat anyone's bread without paying; rather we worked night and day, with difficulty and hardship, so as not to be a burden to any of you;
2TH 3:9 not because we do not have the right, but in order to offer ourselves to you as a model for you to imitate.
2TH 3:10 Yes, because when we were with you we gave you this command: “If anyone does not want to work, neither let him eat!”
2TH 3:11 Yet we hear that some among you are behaving irresponsibly; not working, just meddling.
2TH 3:12 Now to such individuals we command and exhort by our Lord Jesus Christ that they work in quietness and eat their own bread.
2TH 3:13 But as for you, brothers, do not lose heart in well doing.
2TH 3:14 If anyone does not obey our word in this letter, take note of him and do not associate with him, that he may be shamed;
2TH 3:15 yet do not regard him as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother.
2TH 3:16 Now may the Lord of peace Himself give you the peace during every situation, in every way. The Lord be with you all.
2TH 3:17 The greeting of Paul, with my own hand, which is the ‘trademark’ in every letter that I write.
2TH 3:18 The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.
1TI 1:1 Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the command of God our Savior and Sovereign Jesus Christ our hope,
1TI 1:2 to Timothy, true son by faith: Grace, mercy, peace from God our Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
1TI 1:3 You recall that I urged you to remain in Ephesus, when I went into Macedonia, in order that you should command certain persons to stop teaching a different doctrine
1TI 1:4 and occupying themselves with myths and endless genealogies, which cause disputes rather than the godly training which is by faith.
1TI 1:5 Now the goal of that command is love, out of a pure heart and a good conscience and a sincere faith;
1TI 1:6 some having strayed from these have been turned aside to empty talk,
1TI 1:7 desiring to be teachers of the law, not understanding either what they say or the things that they affirm.
1TI 1:8 Now we know that the law is good if one uses it correctly,
1TI 1:9 knowing that law is not made for a righteous person but for lawless and rebellious ones, for ungodly and sinners, for unholy and profane, for father-smiters and mother-smiters, for murderers,
1TI 1:10 for fornicators, for sodomites, for kidnappers, for liars, for perjurers, and for whatever else is contrary to the sound doctrine
1TI 1:11 as defined by the Gospel of the glory of the blessed God, with which I was entrusted.
1TI 1:12 I thank Christ Jesus our Lord who enables me, because He considered me faithful, putting me into a ministry;
1TI 1:13 I, who was formerly a blasphemer and a persecutor and arrogant; but I was shown mercy, because being ignorant I did it in unbelief;
1TI 1:14 the grace of our Lord overflowed, along with the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus.
1TI 1:15 Here is a trustworthy word, worthy of total acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners—of whom I am chief;
1TI 1:16 precisely for this reason I was shown mercy, that in me, the ‘chief’, Jesus Christ might display all his forbearance, as an example for those who are going to rely on Him into eternal life.
1TI 1:17 Now to the King eternal, immortal, invisible, to God who alone is wise, be honor and glory forever and ever. Amen.
1TI 1:18 Son Timothy, I am giving you this charge in accordance with the prophecies about you that lead the way, that in them you may wage the good warfare,
1TI 1:19 holding on to faith and a good conscience (which some having rejected have suffered shipwreck concerning the Faith;
1TI 1:20 of whom are Hymenaeus and Alexander—whom I have handed over to Satan that they may be taught not to blaspheme).
1TI 2:1 Therefore I exhort first of all that supplications, prayers, intercessions and thanksgivings be made on behalf of all men
1TI 2:2 —on behalf of kings and all who are in authority, that we may live a tranquil and quiet life in all godliness and dignity.
1TI 2:3 Because this is good and pleasing to our Savior God,
1TI 2:4 who desires all men to be saved and to come into a real knowledge of Truth.
1TI 2:5 For there is one God, and one Mediator between God and men—a man!—Jesus Christ,
1TI 2:6 who gave Himself as a ransom on behalf of all people (to be testified in its own seasons),
1TI 2:7 to which ransom I was appointed a herald and an apostle—I am telling the truth in Christ, I am not lying—a teacher of nations in faith and truth.
1TI 2:8 So I desire that the men in every place pray, lifting up holy hands without anger or argument.
1TI 2:9 Similarly the women also, dressing themselves in appropriate clothing, with modesty and good sense; not with braided hair or gold or pearls or expensive clothes,
1TI 2:10 but with good works, which is appropriate to women who profess godliness.
1TI 2:11 Let a woman learn in silence, in full subordination.
1TI 2:12 I do not permit a woman to teach or to have authority over a man, but to be in silence.
1TI 2:13 For Adam was formed first, then Eve.
1TI 2:14 Also, Adam was not deceived; rather, the woman, being deceived, became a transgressor.
1TI 2:15 However, she will be saved through the Childbirth—if they continue in faith, love and holiness, with self-control.
1TI 3:1 Here is a trustworthy word: if a man aspires to the position of overseer, he desires a good work.
1TI 3:2 Now then, it is obligatory for the overseer to be above reproach, a one woman man, temperate, sensible, respectable, hospitable, good at teaching,
1TI 3:3 not a drinker, not a bully, not corrupt [financially], but gentle, peaceful, not greedy;
1TI 3:4 one who rules his own house well, having children who obey him with due respect
1TI 3:5 (for if a man does not know how to rule his own house, how can he take care of God's congregation?);
1TI 3:6 not a recent convert, lest being puffed up he fall into the same judgment that the devil did.
1TI 3:7 Also, it is necessary for him to have a good reputation with those who are outside the congregation, so as not to fall into reproach and the devil's snare.
1TI 3:8 Similarly, deacons must be respectable, not deceitful, not heavy drinkers, not corrupt [financially];
1TI 3:9 holding the mystery of the faith with a pure conscience.
1TI 3:10 But let these also first be tested; then, if they are blameless, let them serve as deacons.
1TI 3:11 Similarly, women must be respectable, not slanderers, temperate, trustworthy in everything.
1TI 3:12 Let deacons be one woman men, ruling their children and their own houses well.
1TI 3:13 For those who have served well as deacons obtain for themselves a good standing and considerable confidence in the faith which is in Christ Jesus.
1TI 3:14 Although I hope to come to you shortly, I am writing these things to you
1TI 3:15 in case I am delayed, so that you may know how it is necessary to conduct oneself in God's household, which is the Church of the living God, pillar and foundation of the truth.
1TI 3:16 Yes, the mystery of our religion is confessedly great: God was manifested in flesh, was vindicated in spirit, was revealed to angels, was proclaimed among nations, was believed in the world, was received up in glory!
1TI 4:1 Now the Spirit says explicitly that in later times some will fall away from the faith, paying attention to deceiving spirits and to things taught by demons
1TI 4:2 —through hypocritical liars whose own consciences have been cauterized,
1TI 4:3 who forbid to marry and to eat foods that God created to be received with thanksgiving by those who believe and really know the truth.
1TI 4:4 For every creature of God is good, and nothing is to be rejected if it is received with thanksgiving,
1TI 4:5 because it is consecrated through the Word of God and prayer.
1TI 4:6 If you instruct the brothers in these things you will be a good servant of Jesus Christ, brought up in the words of the faith and of the good doctrine that you have faithfully followed.
1TI 4:7 But reject godless myths and old-wives' tales; rather, exercise yourself toward godliness.
1TI 4:8 Now physical exercise has some value, but godliness has value in all things, holding promises for both this present life and the one to come.
1TI 4:9 Here is a trustworthy word, worthy of total acceptance
1TI 4:10 (which is also why we labor and suffer reproach): We have set our hope on the living God, who is ‘Savior of all men’, especially of those who believe.
1TI 4:11 Command and teach these things.
1TI 4:12 Let no one look down on your youthfulness, but be an example to the believers in word, in conduct, in love, in spirit, in faith, in purity.
1TI 4:13 Until I come give attention to public reading [of Scripture], to exhortation, to teaching.
1TI 4:14 Do not neglect the gift that is in you, which was ‘given’ to you through prophecy with the laying on of the hands of the body of elders.
1TI 4:15 Cultivate these things; give yourself wholly to them, so that your progress may be evident to all.
1TI 4:16 Take pains with yourself and the doctrine; persevere in those things, because by doing so you will save both yourself and those who hear you.
1TI 5:1 Do not rebuke an older man harshly, but exhort him as a father, younger men as brothers,
1TI 5:2 older women as mothers, younger women as sisters, with all purity.
1TI 5:3 Give financial support to widows who are really ‘widows’.
1TI 5:4 But if any widow has children or grandchildren, let them learn first to demonstrate piety in their own household by repaying their parents, for this is pleasing to God.
1TI 5:5 Now she who is really a widow and desolate has set her hope on God, and continues in supplications and prayers night and day.
1TI 5:6 But she who indulges in pleasure is dead while she lives.
1TI 5:7 You should even command these things, so that they may be blameless.
1TI 5:8 But if anyone does not provide for his own, and especially for those of his household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.
1TI 5:9 No widow should be enrolled unless she is at least sixty, a one man wife,
1TI 5:10 known for good works—she brought up children, she lodged strangers, she washed saints' feet, she relieved the afflicted, she devoted herself to every good work.
1TI 5:11 As for younger widows, do not enroll them; because whenever they are controlled by sensual desires rather than by Christ, they want to marry,
1TI 5:12 coming under judgment because they have broken their first commitment.
1TI 5:13 Not only that, they learn to be idle, going around from house to house; and not only idle, but also gossips and busybodies, saying things they ought not to.
1TI 5:14 So I want the younger widows to marry, to bear children, to manage the home, to give the adversary no occasion for caustic comments.
1TI 5:15 (In fact, some have already turned aside after Satan.)
1TI 5:16 If any man or woman who is a believer has widows, let them relieve them and not burden the congregation, so that it may relieve those who are widows indeed.
1TI 5:17 Let the elders who lead well be counted worthy of a double honorarium, especially those who labor in word and teaching.
1TI 5:18 For the Scripture says: “You shall not muzzle an ox while it treads out grain,” and “The worker is worthy of his wages.”
1TI 5:19 Do not entertain an accusation against an elder except on the basis of two or three witnesses.
1TI 5:20 Those who are sinning rebuke publicly, so that the rest also may be in fear.
1TI 5:21 I charge you in the presence of God and Sovereign Jesus Christ and the elect angels that you observe these things without prejudgment, doing nothing by partiality.
1TI 5:22 Do not lay hands [in ordination] hastily on anyone, do not thereby participate in the sins of others. Keep yourself pure.
1TI 5:23 Stop drinking only water; use a little wine because of your stomach and your frequent infirmities.
1TI 5:24 The sins of some men are obvious, leading the way into judgment, while those of others trail behind.
1TI 5:25 So also the good works are obvious; even the ones that are not, cannot be hidden.
1TI 6:1 As many as are under the yoke of slavery should consider their own owners to be worthy of full respect, so that God's name and doctrine not be slandered.
1TI 6:2 Those who have owners who are believers must not disregard them because they are brothers; instead they must serve them even better, because those receiving the good service are believers and beloved. Teach and exhort these things.
1TI 6:3 If anyone teaches differently and does not consent to sound words, the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine that accords with godliness,
1TI 6:4 he is conceited and understands nothing. Rather he is obsessed with controversies and hair-splitting word battles, from which come envy, strife, slanderings, evil suspicions,
1TI 6:5 constant wranglings of men with corrupted minds and destitute of the Truth, who suppose that godliness is a means to financial gain. Keep away from such people.
1TI 6:6 Now godliness with contentment is great gain.
1TI 6:7 We brought nothing into the world and it is certain that neither can we take anything out.
1TI 6:8 So having food and clothing we will be content with that.
1TI 6:9 But those who want to get rich fall into temptation and a snare and into many foolish and harmful desires, that plunge people into ruin and loss;
1TI 6:10 because the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil; in their greediness some have been led away from the faith and have impaled themselves on many distresses.
1TI 6:11 But you, O man of God, flee these things; rather pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, endurance, gentleness.
1TI 6:12 Fight the good fight of faith; take hold of the eternal life into which you were called—indeed, you confessed the good confession in the presence of many witnesses.
1TI 6:13 In the presence of the God who gives life to all things, and of Christ Jesus who testified the good confession before Pontius Pilate, I charge you
1TI 6:14 to keep this commandment without spot, blameless until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ,
1TI 6:15 which He will manifest at the proper time—He who is the blessed and only Sovereign, the King of kings and the Lord of lords;
1TI 6:16 who alone has immortality, residing in unapproachable light; whom no man has seen or can see; to whom be honor and eternal power. Amen.
1TI 6:17 Command those who are rich in this present world not to be haughty, nor to rely upon the uncertainty of riches but on the living God, who richly provides us with everything to enjoy;
1TI 6:18 they are to do good, to be rich in good works, to be generous sharers
1TI 6:19 —storing up for themselves a good foundation against the time to come, so that they may lay hold on the eternal life.
1TI 6:20 O Timothy, guard the deposit! Turn away from the godless, empty chatter and inconsistencies of what is falsely called ‘science’
1TI 6:21 —by professing it some have erred concerning the Faith. The Grace be with you. Amen.
2TI 1:1 Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, according to the promise of life that is in Christ Jesus,
2TI 1:2 to dear son Timothy: Grace, mercy, peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
2TI 1:3 I give thanks to God, whom I serve with a clear conscience like my forefathers did, as I constantly remember you in my prayers, night and day,
2TI 1:4 longing to see you (recalling your tears), that I may be filled with joy;
2TI 1:5 while I call to mind the unfeigned faith that is in you—it resided first in your grandmother Lois and in your mother Eunice and, I am persuaded, in you also.
2TI 1:6 For this reason I am reminding you to rekindle the gift of God which is in you through the laying on of my hands.
2TI 1:7 Because God did not give us a spirit of cowardice, but of power and of love and of self-control.
2TI 1:8 So do not be ashamed to identify with our Lord or with me His prisoner, but join in suffering for the Gospel according to the power of God
2TI 1:9 —the One who saved us and called us with a holy calling, not because of our works but because of His own purpose and grace, which was given to us in Christ Jesus before time began,
2TI 1:10 but has now been revealed through the appearing of our Savior, Jesus Christ, who by means of the Gospel destroyed the death and brought life and immortality to light;
2TI 1:11 to this Gospel I was appointed as a proclaimer, an apostle and a teacher of nations.
2TI 1:12 That is why I am suffering these things, yet I am not ashamed because I know in whom I have believed and am certain that He is able to guard my deposit until that Day.
2TI 1:13 Hold fast the standard of sound teaching that you heard from me, through the faith and love in Christ Jesus.
2TI 1:14 Guard the good deposit by the Holy Spirit who dwells in us.
2TI 1:15 This you know, that all those in Asia have been turned away from me, including Phygellus and Hermogenes.
2TI 1:16 May the Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, because he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chain;
2TI 1:17 rather, when he arrived in Rome he searched diligently for me until he found me
2TI 1:18 (may the Lord grant to him to find mercy from the Lord in that Day); you also know very well in how many ways he served in Ephesus.
2TI 2:1 So you, my son, be strengthened by the grace that is in Christ Jesus.
2TI 2:2 Also, the things that you have heard from me among many witnesses, commit the same to faithful men who will be competent to teach others also.
2TI 2:3 You therefore are to endure hardship as a good soldier of Jesus Christ.
2TI 2:4 No one serving as a soldier gets entangled in the affairs of civilian life; he wants to please the one who enlisted him.
2TI 2:5 Further, if anyone competes in athletics, he is not crowned unless he competes according to the rules
2TI 2:6 —the hardworking farmer should be the first to receive of the fruits.
2TI 2:7 Ponder what I am saying; may the Lord indeed give you understanding in it all.
2TI 2:8 Keep thinking of Jesus Christ, raised from the dead, of David's seed; this is my gospel,
2TI 2:9 for which I am suffering to the point of being in chains like a criminal, but the Word of God is not chained.
2TI 2:10 This is why I endure it all: for the sake of the chosen ones, that they also may obtain the salvation that is in Christ Jesus, with eternal glory.
2TI 2:11 This is a trustworthy word: If, indeed, we died together, we will also live together;
2TI 2:12 if we endure, we will also reign together; if we deny, He will also deny us;
2TI 2:13 if we are faithless, He remains faithful —He is incapable of denying Himself.
2TI 2:14 Keep reiterating these things, exhorting them before the Lord not to argue about words to no useful purpose—it just ruins the hearers.
2TI 2:15 Make every effort to render yourself approved by God, a worker who does not need to be ashamed, handling the Word of the Truth correctly.
2TI 2:16 But shun godless, empty chatter, because those who do it will become increasingly godless,
2TI 2:17 and their word will spread like gangrene—among them are Hymenaeus and Philetus,
2TI 2:18 who have wandered away from the Truth, saying that the resurrection has already occurred; and they overturn the faith of some.
2TI 2:19 Nevertheless, the solid foundation of God stands firm, having this seal: “The Lord knows those who are His,” and let everyone who claims the name of the Lord keep away from unrighteousness.
2TI 2:20 Now in a large house there are not only vessels of gold and silver, but also of wood and clay; some, to be sure, are for honor, but some are for dishonor.
2TI 2:21 So if anyone cleanses himself from the latter, he will be a vessel for honor, sanctified and useful to the Master, prepared for every good work.
2TI 2:22 Flee the lusts of youth; but pursue righteousness, faith, love, peace, along with those who call on the Lord out of a pure heart.
2TI 2:23 Refuse foolish and ignorant arguments, knowing that they breed quarrels.
2TI 2:24 Now a slave of the Lord should not quarrel but be gentle towards all, skillful at teaching, forbearing,
2TI 2:25 correcting courteously those who oppose him, in hopes that God may grant them repentance leading to a real knowledge of Truth,
2TI 2:26 and that they may retrieve their senses out of the devil's snare (having been taken captive by him to do his will).
2TI 3:1 Now understand this: In the last days there will be grievous times;
2TI 3:2 because people will be self-lovers, money lovers, boasters, arrogant, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, ungrateful, unholy,
2TI 3:3 without family affection, unforgiving, slanderers, without self-control, brutal, despisers of good,
2TI 3:4 betrayers, reckless, conceited, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God;
2TI 3:5 wearing a form of godliness while having denied its power! You must avoid such people;
2TI 3:6 because they are the sort that press into households and ‘capture’ gullible women loaded down with sins, who are led along by various lusts,
2TI 3:7 always learning yet never being able to come to a real knowledge of truth.
2TI 3:8 Just as Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses, so also these oppose the truth—men of depraved mind, disqualified as regards the faith—
2TI 3:9 but they will not advance any further because, as in the case of the former, their folly will become evident to all.
2TI 3:10 You, however, have carefully followed my doctrine, my lifestyle, my purpose, faith, patience, love, endurance;
2TI 3:11 the persecutions and sufferings that happened to me at Antioch, at Iconium, at Lystra—what persecutions I endured; yet the Lord delivered me out of them all.
2TI 3:12 In fact, any one who desires to live a godly life in Christ Jesus will be persecuted;
2TI 3:13 while malignant men and imposters will grow worse and worse, deceiving and being deceived.
2TI 3:14 But you, continue in the things you have learned and to which you were committed, knowing from whom you learned,
2TI 3:15 and that from infancy you have known the Sacred Scriptures which are able to make you wise into salvation through the faith that is in Christ Jesus.
2TI 3:16 All Scripture is God-breathed and is valuable for teaching, for reproving, for correcting, for training in righteousness,
2TI 3:17 so that the man of God may be fully competent, thoroughly equipped for every good work.
2TI 4:1 Now then, in the presence of God and the Lord Jesus Christ, who is about to judge both living and dead, with a view to His appearing and His Kingdom, I give you this charge:
2TI 4:2 Proclaim the Word; be ready in season and out of season; correct, rebuke and exhort, with lots of patience and teaching.
2TI 4:3 Because the time will come when they will not tolerate the sound doctrine; rather, they will accumulate for themselves a great many teachers who will tickle their ears according to their lusts
2TI 4:4 —yes, they will turn their ears away from the Truth and be turned aside to fables.
2TI 4:5 But you, be sober in all things, endure hardship, do the work of an evangelist, fulfill your ministry.
2TI 4:6 For I am already being poured out like a drink offering, and the time of my departure has come.
2TI 4:7 I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.
2TI 4:8 Now the crown of the righteousness is reserved for me, which the Lord, the righteous Judge, will award to me on that Day; and not only to me, but also to all those who have longed for His appearing.
2TI 4:9 Do your best to come to me quickly;
2TI 4:10 for Demas, loving this present world, has deserted me and gone to Thessalonica—Crescens to Galatia, Titus to Dalmatia.
2TI 4:11 Only Luke is with me. Take Mark and bring him with you, for he is useful to me for ministry.
2TI 4:12 Tychicus I sent to Ephesus.
2TI 4:13 Bring the cloak that I left with Carpus at Troas, when you come—and the books, especially the parchments.
2TI 4:14 Alexander the coppersmith did me a lot of harm; may the Lord repay him according to his deeds.
2TI 4:15 You also guard against him, because he strongly opposed our words.
2TI 4:16 At my first defense no one came to help me, but all deserted me. May it not be held against them.
2TI 4:17 But the Lord stood by me and strengthened me, so that through me the message might be fully proclaimed and all the nations might hear. Also, I was delivered out of a lion's mouth;
2TI 4:18 and the Lord will deliver me from every evil work and save me into His heavenly Kingdom; to whom be the glory for ever and ever. Amen.
2TI 4:19 Greet Prisca and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus.
2TI 4:20 Erastus stayed in Corinth, while I left Trophimus sick in Miletus.
2TI 4:21 Do your best to come before winter. Eubulus greets you, as do Pudens, Linus, Claudia and all the brothers.
2TI 4:22 The Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. The Grace be with you. Amen.
TIT 1:1 Paul, a slave of God and an apostle of Jesus Christ according to the faith of God's elect and a real knowledge of the Truth that accords with godliness,
TIT 1:2 in hope of eternal life—which life God, who cannot lie, promised before the ages of time
TIT 1:3 but has manifested by a proclamation of His Word at chosen times, which word was entrusted to me by the command of our Savior God;
TIT 1:4 to Titus, a true son in a common faith: Grace, mercy, peace, from Father God and Sovereign Jesus Christ, our Savior.
TIT 1:5 I left you in Crete for this reason, that you should set in order the things that were lacking and appoint elders in every town as I directed you
TIT 1:6 —if a man is blameless, a one-woman man, having children who believe and who are not open to the charge of being wild or disobedient.
TIT 1:7 Because as an administrator under God the overseer must be blameless; not self-willed, not hotheaded, not given to wine, not a bully, not avaricious;
TIT 1:8 but rather hospitable, a lover of what is good, prudent, just, holy, disciplined;
TIT 1:9 holding fast the trustworthy Word as taught, so that he may be competent both to exhort with the sound doctrine and to correct those who oppose it.
TIT 1:10 Because there really are lots of rebels, loudmouths and deceivers, especially those of the circumcision group,
TIT 1:11 who must be silenced—they are ruining whole households, teaching things that they ought not, and for dishonest gain!
TIT 1:12 One of them, a prophet of their own, said, “Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, lazy gluttons.”
TIT 1:13 This testimony is true. Therefore correct them rigorously, that they may be sound in the faith,
TIT 1:14 not paying attention to Jewish fables or to commands of men who are rejecting the truth.
TIT 1:15 To the pure, all things are pure, but to those who are defiled and unbelieving, nothing is pure; in fact, both their minds and their consciences are defiled.
TIT 1:16 They profess to know God, but by their actions they deny Him, being detestable, disobedient and disqualified for any good work.
TIT 2:1 Now you, speak the things that suit sound doctrine:
TIT 2:2 older men are to be sober, dignified, prudent, sound in the faith, in love and in endurance;
TIT 2:3 similarly older women are to be reverent in behavior, not slanderers nor enslaved to much wine, teachers of what is good
TIT 2:4 —so that they may instruct the young women to love their husbands, to love their children,
TIT 2:5 to be prudent, pure, good homemakers, subordinating themselves to their own husbands, so that the Word of God not be maligned.
TIT 2:6 Similarly, exhort the young men to be self-controlled,
TIT 2:7 in all things presenting yourself as an example of good works: showing integrity, dignity and incorruptibility in your teaching
TIT 2:8 —healthy speech, beyond reproach—so that the opponent may be put to shame, having nothing slighting to say about us.
TIT 2:9 Exhort slaves to subordinate themselves to their own owners, to be well pleasing in all things, not talking back,
TIT 2:10 not pilfering but showing total trustworthiness, so as to adorn the doctrine of our Savior God in everything.
TIT 2:11 For the saving grace of God has appeared for all men,
TIT 2:12 teaching us that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live prudently, righteously and godly in this present age,
TIT 2:13 looking for the blessed hope, even the glorious appearing of our great God and Savior, Jesus Christ,
TIT 2:14 who gave Himself for us, so that He might redeem us from all lawlessness and purify for Himself a special people, zealous for good works.
TIT 2:15 Speak these things, whether you exhort or reprove, with all authority. Let no one disdain you.
TIT 3:1 Remind them to subordinate themselves to rulers and authorities, to be obedient, to be ready for every good work,
TIT 3:2 to slander no one, to be peaceable, gentle, demonstrating true humility to all men.
TIT 3:3 Because we ourselves were also foolish at one time, disobedient, being deceived, being enslaved to various lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, detestable, hating one another.
TIT 3:4 But when the kindness of our Savior God and His love toward mankind manifested itself,
TIT 3:5 He saved us—not because of righteous deeds that we ourselves had done but according to His mercy, by means of the bath of regeneration and renewal by the Holy Spirit,
TIT 3:6 whom He poured out on us abundantly through Jesus Christ our Savior,
TIT 3:7 so that having been justified by His grace we might become heirs according to the hope of eternal life.
TIT 3:8 The above is a trustworthy statement and I want you to insist on these things, so that those who have trusted in God may be concerned to take the lead in good works. These things are good and profitable for mankind.
TIT 3:9 But avoid foolish arguments and genealogies and contentions and disputes about the law, because they are unprofitable and useless.
TIT 3:10 Excommunicate a divisive man after a first and second admonition,
TIT 3:11 knowing that such a person has been perverted and is sinning, being self-condemned.
TIT 3:12 As soon as I send Artemas or Tychicus to you, do your best to come to me at Nicopolis, because I have decided to spend the winter there.
TIT 3:13 Send Zenas the lawyer and Apollos on their way without delay, that they may lack nothing.
TIT 3:14 And let our people also learn to maintain good works, to meet pressing needs, that they not be unfruitful.
TIT 3:15 All who are with me greet you. Greet those who love us in faith. Grace be with you all. Amen.
PHM 1:1 Paul, a prisoner for Jesus Christ, and brother Timothy, to the beloved Philemon, our fellow worker,
PHM 1:2 and to the beloved Apphia and our fellow soldier Archippus, and to the congregation at your (sg) house:
PHM 1:3 Grace to you (pl) and peace from God our Father and Sovereign Jesus Christ.
PHM 1:4 I always thank my God as I make mention of you (sg) in my prayers,
PHM 1:5 hearing of your love and faith that you have toward the Lord Jesus, and for all the saints,
PHM 1:6 so that the sharing of your (sg) faith may become powerful through a full understanding of every good thing that is among you (pl) who are in Christ Jesus;
PHM 1:7 yes, we have much thanksgiving and encouragement because of your (sg) love, in that the hearts of the saints have been refreshed through you, brother.
PHM 1:8 Now then, though I have all boldness in Christ to order you (sg) to do what is right,
PHM 1:9 I—being none other than Paul the old man and now also a prisoner for Jesus Christ—would rather appeal to you, for love's sake.
PHM 1:10 I appeal to you on behalf of the son whom I begot while in my chains, Onesimus, whom I am sending back
PHM 1:11 —formerly he was unprofitable to you, but now he is profitable, both to you and to me.
PHM 1:12 So receive him, who is my very heart
PHM 1:13 —I would have liked to keep him with me, so that he might minister to me in your place, while I am in chains for the Gospel,
PHM 1:14 but I did not want to do anything without your consent, so that your contribution might be voluntary, not as an imposition.
PHM 1:15 Perhaps this is why he was removed for a while, so that you would have him forever
PHM 1:16 —no longer as a slave, but more than a slave, a beloved brother, very much to me but even more to you, both in flesh and in the Lord.
PHM 1:17 So if you consider me a partner, receive him as if it were me.
PHM 1:18 If he wronged you or owes anything, charge it to me.
PHM 1:19 I, Paul, am writing with my own hand, “I will repay” (rather than say to you that you actually owe me your very self!).
PHM 1:20 Yes brother, let me have this benefit from you in the Lord; refresh my heart in the Lord.
PHM 1:21 Being confident of your obedience, I write to you, knowing that you (sg) will do even more than I say.
PHM 1:22 But meanwhile, do prepare a guest room for me, because I hope that through your (pl) prayers I will be graciously bestowed on you (pl).
PHM 1:23 Epaphras, my fellow prisoner for Christ Jesus, greets you (sg),
PHM 1:24 as do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas and Luke, my fellow workers.
PHM 1:25 The grace of our Lord Jesus be with your (pl) spirit. Amen.
HEB 1:1 God, having spoken to the fathers through the prophets in many parts and in various ways, in the past,
HEB 1:2 has at the end of these days spoken to us by Son, whom He appointed heir of all things, through whom also He made the ages;
HEB 1:3 who being the projection of His glory and the very image of His essence, and sustaining all things by the expression of His[S] own power, when He had by Himself provided purification for our sins He sat down on the highest Majesty's right,
HEB 1:4 having become so much superior to the angels as He has inherited a more excellent name than they have.
HEB 1:5 For to which of the angels did He[F] ever say, “You are my Son, today I begot you,” and again, “I will be ‘Father’ to Him, and He will be ‘Son’ to me?”
HEB 1:6 Again, when He introduces the Firstborn into the inhabited earth He says, “Let all God's angels worship Him[S].”
HEB 1:7 Further, about the angels He[F] says, “Who makes His angels winds, His servants flames of fire”;
HEB 1:8 while to the Son He says: “Your throne, O God, is forever and ever; ‘Scepter of Uprightness’ is the scepter of Your kingdom.
HEB 1:9 You have loved righteousness and hated lawlessness, therefore God, Your God, has anointed You with the oil of exultation beyond Your companions.”
HEB 1:10 Also: “You, Lord, in the beginning, laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are works of Your hands;
HEB 1:11 they will perish but You continue on —they will all grow old like a garment;
HEB 1:12 You will roll them up like a cloak and they will be changed, while You stay the same and Your years will never end.”
HEB 1:13 On the other hand, to which of the angels did He ever say, “Sit on my right until I place your enemies as a stool under your feet”?
HEB 1:14 Are they not all ministering spirits being sent to serve those who are going to inherit salvation?
HEB 2:1 So then, we really must pay the utmost attention to the things we have heard, so that we not drift away.
HEB 2:2 For if the word spoken through angels became binding, and every violation and disobedience received a deserved penalty,
HEB 2:3 how shall we escape if we are careless about that tremendous salvation?—it received its beginning through the Lord's declaration and was confirmed to us by those who heard Him[S],
HEB 2:4 God adding His[F] attestation by signs, wonders, various miracles, and distributions of the Holy Spirit according to His own will.
HEB 2:5 Because it is not to angels that He has subjected the coming inhabited earth, about which we are speaking;
HEB 2:6 rather, there is a place where someone testified saying: “What is man that You are mindful of him, or son of man that you care for him?
HEB 2:7 You made him lower than the angels, for a little while; You crowned him with glory and honor,
HEB 2:8 You subjected all things under his feet.” It follows that in subjecting all things to him, He left nothing that is not so subjected. However, we do not yet see everything subjected to him, at present.
HEB 2:9 But we do see Jesus, who ‘was made lower than the angels, for a little while’ (in order to suffer death), ‘crowned with glory and honor’—this, by the grace of God, so that He[S] might taste death on behalf of everyone.
HEB 2:10 Because it was appropriate to Him[F], for whom are all things and through whom are all things, in bringing many sons into glory, to complete the Author of their salvation through sufferings.
HEB 2:11 For both He[S] who is sanctifying and those who are being sanctified are all from One, for which reason He is not ashamed to call them ‘brothers’,
HEB 2:12 saying, “I will declare Your name to my brothers; in the midst of the congregation I will sing praise to You.”
HEB 2:13 And again, “I will put my trust in Him[F]”; and again, “Here am I and the children whom God has given me.”
HEB 2:14 Since, then, the children have flesh and blood as their share, He[S] Himself likewise partook of the same, in order that through His death He might abolish the one who had the power of death—that is, the devil—
HEB 2:15 and set free these [the children] who during their whole lifetime were subject to slavery through fear of death.
HEB 2:16 (Now surely He does not assist angels, but He does assist Abraham's seed.)
HEB 2:17 That is why He was obliged to become like those ‘brothers’ in all respects, so that He could be a merciful and faithful high priest, in what concerns God, with a view to making propitiation for the sins of the people.
HEB 2:18 For in that in which He Himself endured suffering, having been tested, He is able to assist those who are being tested.
HEB 3:1 So then, holy brothers, you who share in the celestial calling, do contemplate the Apostle and High Priest of our confession, Jesus Christ!
HEB 3:2 who was faithful to the One who appointed Him, as also was Moses in all His[F] house.
HEB 3:3 For this One has been counted worthy of more glory than was Moses, just as the builder of a house has more honor than the house itself
HEB 3:4 —every house is built by someone, but He who built all things is God—
HEB 3:5 also, Moses was indeed faithful as a servant in all His house, providing evidence of those things that would later be spoken,
HEB 3:6 but Christ is faithful as a Son over His house, whose house are we, if, that is, we hold fast the confidence, even the boast, of the Hope firm to the end.
HEB 3:7 Therefore—just as the Holy Spirit says: “Today, if you would hear His voice,
HEB 3:8 do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion, during the time of the testing in the desert,
HEB 3:9 where your fathers tested me, proved me and saw my works for forty years.
HEB 3:10 In consequence I became very angry with that generation and said, ‘Their heart always leads them astray; they have not known my ways.’
HEB 3:11 So I took an oath in my wrath, ‘As if they will ever enter my rest!’ ”
HEB 3:12 —take care, brothers, that there not be a malignant heart of unbelief in any of you, so as to go away from the living God;
HEB 3:13 rather, exhort yourselves every day, while it is called ‘today’, so that none of you be hardened through sin's deceitfulness.
HEB 3:14 For we have become associates of the Christ, if, that is, we hold fast the beginning of the Endeavor firm to the end,
HEB 3:15 while it is still being said, “Today, if you would hear His voice, do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion.”
HEB 3:16 So who were they who, upon hearing, rebelled? Really now, was it not all those who came out of Egypt by Moses?
HEB 3:17 And with whom was He[F] angry for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose corpses fell in the desert?
HEB 3:18 Or to whom did He swear that they would not enter His rest, if not to those who disobeyed?
HEB 3:19 So we see that they were not able to enter because of unbelief.
HEB 4:1 Therefore we should fear, since a promise of entering His rest still stands, lest any one of you should expect to have come short of it.
HEB 4:2 Really, because we are continually hearing Good News just like they did, but the word that they heard did not profit them, since they were not intimately united with the faith of those who obeyed.
HEB 4:3 Now we who have believed do enter that rest, just as He has said, “So I took an oath in my wrath, ‘As if they will ever enter my rest!’ ”—His works were certainly finished from the foundation of the world,
HEB 4:4 because somewhere He has spoken about the seventh day like this, “And on the seventh day God rested from all His works,”
HEB 4:5 while again, in this place, “As if they will ever enter my rest!”
HEB 4:6 Therefore since it remains for some to enter into it, and those who formerly had the Good News proclaimed to them did not enter because of disobedience,
HEB 4:7 He again designates a certain day, after such a long time, saying through David: “Today” (as was stated above), “Today, if you would hear His voice, do not harden your hearts.”
HEB 4:8 Because if Jesus had given them rest, He would not have spoken afterward of another day.
HEB 4:9 So then, there remains a Sabbath rest for the people of God.
HEB 4:10 Further, the one having entered into His rest has himself also rested from his own works, just as God did from His.
HEB 4:11 Therefore, let us take pains to enter into that rest so that no one may fall through the same pattern of disobedience.
HEB 4:12 Because the Word of God is living and efficient, and sharper than any two-edged sword, actually penetrating to the point of separating soul and spirit, joints and marrow; in fact, it is able to evaluate a heart's reflections and intentions.
HEB 4:13 Nothing in all creation is hidden from His sight; rather all things are naked and open to the eyes of Him to whom we must give account.
HEB 4:14 Therefore, since we have a Great High Priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast the Confession.
HEB 4:15 For we do not have a High Priest who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but He was tested in all points, in similar ways, without sin.
HEB 4:16 So let us approach the throne of grace with confidence, that we may receive mercy and find grace, for timely help.
HEB 5:1 Now every high priest taken from among men is appointed to act on behalf of men in things pertaining to God, that he may offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins,
HEB 5:2 being able to deal gently with those who sin in ignorance and go astray, since he himself is also subject to weakness.
HEB 5:3 Because of this he must offer sacrifices for his own sins as well, just as he does for the people's.
HEB 5:4 Also, no one receives this honor on his own, but upon being called by God, just like Aaron.
HEB 5:5 So also Christ did not exalt Himself to become High Priest, but it was He[F] who said to Him[S], “You are my Son; today I have begotten You.”
HEB 5:6 Just as He[F] also says in another place, “You are a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek.”
HEB 5:7 He[S], in the days of His flesh, having offered up both prayers and supplications, with a loud cry and tears, to the One who was able to save Him from death, and having been answered because of His godly fear,
HEB 5:8 although being SON, He learned obedience by the things which He suffered.
HEB 5:9 And having been completed He became the Source of eternal salvation for all those obeying Him,
HEB 5:10 having been designated by God as High Priest ‘according to the order of Melchizedek’;
HEB 5:11 concerning whom we have much to say, but it is hard to explain, since you have become sluggish in hearing.
HEB 5:12 Really, because although by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you the elementary principles of God's oracles all over again; you have come to the point of needing milk, not solid food!
HEB 5:13 Surely; whoever lives on milk is an infant, and therefore unskilled in the Word of righteousness.
HEB 5:14 On the other hand, solid food is for the mature, those who by habitual use have trained their senses to distinguish good from bad.
HEB 6:1 Therefore, leaving the elementary teaching about Christ, let us move on toward perfection, not laying again a foundation of repentance from dead works and trust in God,
HEB 6:2 of teaching about baptisms, of laying on of hands, of resurrection of the dead, and of eternal judgment.
HEB 6:3 We will do this, that is, if indeed God should permit it.
HEB 6:4 Because, it is impossible to bring back into repentance those who were once for all enlightened, who have partaken of the heavenly gift and were made sharers in the Holy Spirit,
HEB 6:5 who have experienced God's good event and capabilities of the coming age,
HEB 6:6 and yet have fallen away—they would be crucifying the Son of God all over again, just for themselves, holding Him up to contempt.
HEB 6:7 Now the ground that drinks in the rain that frequently falls on it and produces a crop useful to those for whom it is really cultivated receives blessing from God;
HEB 6:8 but should it bear thorns and thistles, it is disqualified, almost a curse, whose destiny is a burning.
HEB 6:9 For all that, dear ones, we are confident of the better things concerning you—things that accompany salvation—even though we speak like this.
HEB 6:10 Because God is not unjust so as to ignore your work, even the labor of love you have invested in His name, in that you have ministered to the saints and continue to do so.
HEB 6:11 You see, we really do want each of you to show this same diligence to the very end, so as to fulfill the hope;
HEB 6:12 so that you not become lazy, but rather imitators of those who through faith and patience inherit the promises.
HEB 6:13 Now when God made a promise to Abraham, since He had no one greater to swear by, He swore by Himself
HEB 6:14 saying, “Indeed, blessing I will bless you, and multiplying I will multiply you.”
HEB 6:15 And so, after he had been patient, he obtained the promise.
HEB 6:16 Because since men swear by the greater, and for them the confirming oath puts an end to every dispute,
HEB 6:17 similarly God, being determined to show even more clearly to the heirs of the promise the unchanging nature of His purpose, guaranteed it by an oath,
HEB 6:18 so that by two unalterable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we should have a strong encouragement, we who have taken refuge by grasping the hope set before us;
HEB 6:19 which hope we have as an anchor for the soul, both certain and secure, actually entering the inner sanctuary behind the curtain,
HEB 6:20 where Forerunner Jesus has entered on our behalf, having become High Priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek.
HEB 7:1 Now this Melchizedek—king of Salem, priest of God Most High, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him,
HEB 7:2 to whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of all (first, his name means ‘king of righteousness’, and then again ‘king of Salem’, which means ‘king of peace’),
HEB 7:3 without father, without mother, without genealogy; having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but having been made like the Son of God—remains a priest continually.
HEB 7:4 Now consider how great this personage was, to whom even the patriarch Abraham gave a tenth of the spoils:
HEB 7:5 You see, those of the sons of Levi who receive the priesthood have a command, according to the Law, to collect a tithe from the people—that is, from their brothers—even though they too came out of Abraham's body;
HEB 7:6 but he whose descent is not counted among them collected a tithe from Abraham and blessed him who had the promises.
HEB 7:7 Now without dispute the lesser is blessed by the greater.
HEB 7:8 Also, here men who die receive tithes, but there he of whom it is testified that he lives
HEB 7:9 —in a word, even Levi, who receives tithes, paid the tithe through Abraham,
HEB 7:10 because he was still in the reproductive system of his forefather when Melchizedek met him.
HEB 7:11 Now then, if there could be perfection through the Levitical priesthood (for on the basis of it the people had received the Law), what further need would there be for a different kind of priest to arise according to the order of Melchizedek, rather than being called according to the order of Aaron?
HEB 7:12 (Because when the priesthood is changed there is also a change of law, of necessity.)
HEB 7:13 For He of whom these things are said belongs to a different tribe, from which no one has officiated at the altar.
HEB 7:14 For it is evident that our Lord arose out of Judah, of which tribe Moses spoke nothing concerning priesthood.
HEB 7:15 And it all becomes clearer still if a different kind of priest, in the likeness of Melchizedek, appears,
HEB 7:16 who has come, not on the basis of a law about a physical rule but on the basis of the power of an indestructible life.
HEB 7:17 Because He testifies: “You are a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek.”
HEB 7:18 You see, there is an annulling of the former rule because of its weakness and uselessness
HEB 7:19 (for the Law made nothing perfect), and a bringing in of a better hope, through which we draw near to God.
HEB 7:20 Further, inasmuch as it was not without the taking of an oath
HEB 7:21 —they indeed had become priests without an oath-taking, but He[S] with an oath by Him[F] who said to Him[S]: “The Lord has sworn and will not change His[F] mind; you are a priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek”
HEB 7:22 —by so much Jesus has become the guarantee of a better covenant.
HEB 7:23 Also, there have been many priests because death prevented them from continuing in office;
HEB 7:24 while He[S], because He continues forever, has an unchangeable priesthood.
HEB 7:25 Therefore He is able to save absolutely those who come to God through Him, since He always lives and can intercede on their behalf.
HEB 7:26 Now such a High Priest was fitting for us—holy, innocent, undefiled, having been set apart from sinners, and having become higher than the heavens—
HEB 7:27 who, unlike those high priests, does not need to offer up daily sacrifices, first for His own sins and then for the sins of the people; because He did this once for all when He offered up Himself.
HEB 7:28 The Law appoints as high priest men who have weakness, but the word of the oath, that came after the Law, appointed Son, forever perfect.
HEB 8:1 Now the main point of the things we are saying is this: We do have such a High Priest, who sat down at the right of the Majesty's throne in the heavens,
HEB 8:2 Minister of the Holy Places, that is, of the true Tabernacle which the Lord set up, not man.
HEB 8:3 Every high priest is appointed to offer both gifts and sacrifices (it follows that it is necessary for this One also to have something He might offer)
HEB 8:4 —if He were on earth He would not be a priest, there already being priests who offer the gifts according to the Law;
HEB 8:5 who serve a copy and shadow of the heavenly things (that is why Moses was warned by God when he was ready to assemble the Tabernacle: “See to it,” He says, “that you make everything according to the pattern shown to you on the mountain”)—
HEB 8:6 but now He has obtained a more excellent ministry, just as He is Mediator of a better covenant, which was enacted as law on the basis of better promises.
HEB 8:7 Now if there had been nothing wrong with that first covenant, no place would have been sought for a second one;
HEB 8:8 but finding fault with them He says: “Listen! Days are coming,” says the Lord, “when I will establish a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah
HEB 8:9 —not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers in the day when I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt, because they did not abide by my covenant and so I disregarded them,” says the Lord.
HEB 8:10 “Now this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days,” says the Lord, “I will put my laws into their mind and write them on their hearts; and I will be their God and they will be my people.
HEB 8:11 Further, not one of them will teach his neighbor and not one his brother saying, ‘Get to know the Lord!’ because they all will know me, from the least of them to the greatest of them.
HEB 8:12 For I will be merciful to their wrongdoings; I will not at all remember their sins and their lawless deeds.”
HEB 8:13 By saying ‘new’ He has made the first one ‘old’; and what is obsolete and aging is near the end.
HEB 9:1 Now that first covenant did indeed have regulations for divine service and the earthly sanctuary.
HEB 9:2 Yes, a tabernacle was set up: the first part, which is called the Holy Place, in which were the lamp stand, the table and the showbread;
HEB 9:3 and behind the second curtain an area called the Holy of Holies,
HEB 9:4 having a golden censer and the ark of the covenant overlaid on all sides with gold—in it were a golden jar holding the manna, Aaron's rod that budded, and the stone tablets of the covenant;
HEB 9:5 while above it were cherubim of glory overshadowing the mercy seat (this is not the place to go into detail about them).
HEB 9:6 Now when these things had been thus prepared, the priests continually went into the first part, performing the divine services,
HEB 9:7 but into the second one only the high priest could go, once a year and only with blood, which he offered for himself and for the people's sins of ignorance;
HEB 9:8 the Holy Spirit was making clear that the way into the Most Holy Place was not yet open to the public while the first tabernacle was still in existence.
HEB 9:9 It was a figure during the time then present, a time when both gifts and sacrifices were being offered that were incapable of clearing the conscience of the worshiper—
HEB 9:10 they were only about foods and drinks and various ceremonial washings and physical regulations, things imposed until the time of restructuring.
HEB 9:11 But Christ entered once for all into the real Holy Places, having obtained eternal redemption—He had come as High Priest of the good things that are about to be, with the greater and more perfect tabernacle not made with hands, that is to say, not of this creation,
HEB 9:12 and with His own blood, not that of goats and calves.
HEB 9:13 For if the blood of bulls and goats, and the ashes of a heifer sprinkling those who had been ceremonially defiled, restored ceremonial purity to the body,
HEB 9:14 how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the Holy Spirit offered Himself unblemished to God, cleanse your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?
HEB 9:15 For this reason He is mediator of a new covenant, so that those who have been called may receive the promised eternal inheritance—since a death has occurred for the redemption of the transgressions under the first covenant.
HEB 9:16 Now where there is a will, the death of the one who made it must be established;
HEB 9:17 because a will is in force after men are dead, since it never takes effect while the one who made it lives.
HEB 9:18 Therefore, not even the first covenant was inaugurated without blood;
HEB 9:19 because when every commandment of the Law had been proclaimed by Moses to all the people, he took the blood of calves and goats, with water and scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the scroll itself and all the people,
HEB 9:20 saying, “This is the blood of the covenant which God has decreed to you.”
HEB 9:21 Then he sprinkled both the tabernacle and all the vessels of the divine service with the blood in the same way.
HEB 9:22 In fact, according to the Law nearly everything is cleansed with blood, and without shedding of blood there is no remission.
HEB 9:23 So then, it was necessary for the copies of the things in the heavens to be cleansed with such, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than those.
HEB 9:24 For Christ did not enter into Holy Places made by hands, mere copies of the true ones, but into Heaven itself, now to appear in God's presence on our behalf;
HEB 9:25 but not in order to offer Himself repeatedly, like the high priest who entered the Most Holy Place year by year with another's blood
HEB 9:26 —otherwise He would have had to suffer many times since the creation of the world; but now, once for all at the end of the ages, He has been revealed to nullify sin by the sacrifice of Himself.
HEB 9:27 Also, inasmuch as men are destined to die but once, after which the judgment,
HEB 9:28 so the Christ also, having been offered once for all to bear the sins of many—He will appear a second time to those who are eagerly waiting for Him, apart from sin, into salvation.
HEB 10:1 You see, the Law is but a shadow of the good things to come, not their actual matter, so it can never perfect those who approach with the same sacrifices that they offer endlessly, year after year.
HEB 10:2 Otherwise would they not have ceased to be offered, since the worshipers would have had no more consciousness of sins, having been cleansed once for all?
HEB 10:3 However, those sacrifices are an annual reminder of sins,
HEB 10:4 because it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.
HEB 10:5 Therefore, upon coming into the world He[S] says: “Sacrifice and offering You did not desire, but You prepared a body for me;
HEB 10:6 with burnt offerings and sin offerings You were not pleased.
HEB 10:7 Then I said, ‘Yes indeed, I have come to do Your will, O God —thus it is written about me in the scroll of the book.’ ”
HEB 10:8 First He says, “Sacrifices and offerings, burnt offerings and sin offerings You did not desire, nor were You pleased with them” (which are offered according to the Law),
HEB 10:9 then He says, “Yes indeed, I have come to do Your will, O God.” He removes the first in order to establish the second.
HEB 10:10 By that will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
HEB 10:11 Now every priest has stood ministering daily and offering repeatedly the same sacrifices that can never take away sins;
HEB 10:12 but He Himself, having offered for all time one sacrifice for sins, sat down at God's right.
HEB 10:13 Since that time He is waiting until His enemies are placed as a footstool for His feet,
HEB 10:14 because by one offering He has perfected forever those who are being sanctified.
HEB 10:15 Now the Holy Spirit also testifies to us about this, after having foreseen it:
HEB 10:16 “ ‘This is the covenant that I will make with them after those days,’ says the Lord, ‘I will put my laws on their hearts and I will write them on their minds,
HEB 10:17 and I will not at all remember their sins and lawless deeds.’ ”
HEB 10:18 Now where there is remission of these, there is no longer an offering for sin.
HEB 10:19 Therefore, brothers, having courage to enter the Most Holy Place by the blood of Jesus,
HEB 10:20 by a new and living way that He inaugurated for us, through the curtain, that is to say, His flesh,
